PREFACE
This code of the City of Waurika, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to
and including ordinance 01082024-01, passed January 8, 2024. Ordinances of the
City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into
the code and they may not show the original ordinances in their entirety.
Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions concerning
the ordinances listed.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 10142019-04
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A COMPILATION OF CITY ORDINANCES ENTITLED
THE WAURIKA MUNICIPAL CODE, AND ESTABLISHING THE SAME; PROVIDING FOR REPEALER
OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF
AMENDING AND SUPPLEMENTING SUCH CODE; PROVIDING FOR PUBLISHING THE NAME OF EACH
TITLE AND A SUMMARY OF THEIR CONTENT.
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND BOARD OF CITY COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF
WAURIKA, OKLAHOMA:
SECTION I. That the compilation of city ordinances, is hereby adopted and
enacted as the "Waurika Municipal Code, 2019," which code shall supersede all
general and permanent ordinances of the city adopted on or before the 14th day
of October, 2019, to the extent provided in section 2 hereof.
SECTION II. That all provisions of such code shall be in full force and effect
from and after the date of this ordinance's publication and all ordinances of a
general and permanent nature of the city, and not included in such code or
recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are hereby repealed
from and after the effective date of this code.
SECTION III. That the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be
construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a
subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance.
SECTION IV. That unless another penalty is expressly provided, a violation of
any provision of such code, or any provisions of any rule or regulation adopted
or issued pursuant thereto, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs and fees as provided by the code.
SECTION V. That any and all additions and amendments to such code, when passed
and approved in such form as to indicate the intention of the mayor and board
of commissioners to make the same a part of such code, shall be deemed to be
incorporated in such code so that reference to such code shall be understood
and intended to include such additions and amendments.
SECTION VI. That in case of the amendment of any section of such code for which
a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 4 of this
ordinance shall apply to the section as amended.
SECTION VII. Any ordinance adopted after the 14th day of October, 2019, which
amends or refers to ordinances which have been codified in such code shall be
construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of such code.
SECTION VIII. The continuance in effect of temporary and/or special ordinances,
although omitted from this code, shall not be affected by such omission
therefrom and the adoption of this code shall not repeal or amend any such
ordinance or part of such ordinance omitted therefrom. Among the temporary and/
or special ordinances not repealed or amended by this code are the following:
Ordinances relating to special paving or sewer districts and special
assessments; vacating, opening and dedicating specific streets and alleys;
relating to specific bond issues; annexing territory to or excluding it from
the city; designating or amending land use and/or zoning; relating to grade and
alignment of specific streets; granting railroad use of specific streets and
alleys; naming, or changing the name of, specific streets and alleys; abating
special nuisances; and all other temporary and/or special ordinances.
Ordinances granting franchises shall not be repealed or amended by the adoption
of this code.
SECTION IX. This ordinance and the recodification of this code is authorized by
11 O.S. §§ 14-101 - 111, as amended.
APPROVED AND PASSED this 14th day of October, 2019.
                        /s/ Gary Duncan
                        Mayor
ATTEST:
/s/ Michael W. Bryant
Michael W. Bryant, City Clerk
(SEAL)
CHARTER
City
of
WAURIKA
OKLAHOMA
CITY CHARTER
Adopted, election of April 27, 1951
Approved by Governor, May 1, 1951
Amended per Resolution 0115-14-1R,
passed by electors April 1, 2014
Amended per Resolution 08102020-10,
passed by electors November 3, 2020
Amended per Resolution 4900000109,
passed by electors January 22, 2021
Preamble
We, the citizens of the City of Waurika, under authority of the Constitution
and laws of Oklahoma, do ordain and establish this Charter for the City of
Waurika, in Jefferson County, Oklahoma.
Article I
Section 1.
The Municipal corporation now existing and known as the City of Waurika,
Jefferson County, Oklahoma, shall remain and continue to be a body politic and
corporate, under the same name and with the same boundaries, with power and
authority to change its boundaries in the future in the manner provided by the
general laws of the State of Oklahoma. Upon the adoption of this Charter, the
ward boundaries of the City shall be and remain as heretofore fixed and
designated; but the Board of City Commissioners may thereafter change the
boundaries and number of the wards by ordinance.
Article II
Section 2.
The City of Waurika shall have perpetual succession; and it shall own, hold,
and possess all property of every kind heretofore owned, held or possessed by
the said City, and it shall assume, manage, and execute all trusts in any way
connected therewith.
Section 3.
The City shall succeed to all the property rights and liabilities, and shall
acquire and have all benefits, and shall assume all bonds, debts and legal
obligations of the City of Waurika as constituted prior to the adoption of this
Charter.
Section 4.
This City may sue and be sued in the name of "The City of Waurika, Oklahoma",
and in that name it may contract and be contracted with, and may plead,
intervene, prosecute, and defend suits and actions in all courts and before
other bodies and tribunals. The City shall have power to acquire property, real
and personal, by purchase or in any other manner, within or without the limits
of the City, deemed necessary for the public good; and it may own, hold, use,
lease, sell and convey any such property.
Section 5.
The City may have and use a common seal and may alter the same at pleasure.
Section 6.
The City may receive gifts and bequests of property of every kind, either in
fee simple or in trust for charitable or other public purposes and may do all
things necessary or convenient in executing such trust.
Section 7.
Such City shall have the power, within or without its territorial limits, to
acquire by purchase or condemnation or otherwise, construct, lease, supplement,
maintain and operate water works, light and power generating plants and
distribution systems, telephone systems, parks, convention halls, community
buildings and other Municipal buildings, sewer systems and sewer disposal
plants, libraries, hospitals, cemeteries, and all other public utilities or
works which are local in use; and may do all things necessary or convenient in
acquiring, maintaining and operating the same. The said City may purchase, in
whole or in part, any existing public utility, plant, land, or franchise, or
acquire the same by eminent domain or other proceedings at law; and acquire by
purchase, condemnation or otherwise, within or without the territorial limits
of the City, such lands and other property as may be necessary to execute the
powers granted in this section, the City may issue its negotiable bonds to any
amount when authorized by a majority of the tax paying voters voting thereon at
a general or special election.
Section 8.
This City shall have and exercise all powers conferred upon cities by the
Constitution of the State of Oklahoma and by the laws of the State not rendered
inoperative by this Charter. It shall have all legislative, executive,
judicial, proprietary and police powers that shall be necessary, convenient and
proper in conducting the affairs and business of the City and promoting the
interest, rights and welfare of its inhabitants, as fully as if such powers
were enumerated at length herein; and the enumeration of any particular powers
of the City shall not limit the plenary powers thus secured to and provided for
the City. No law hereafter enacted by the State of Oklahoma shall limit,
diminish or repeal any rights and powers conferred on the City by this Charter.
There is expressly reserved to the City all governmental, proprietary and
police powers necessary or appurtenant to Municipal corporations, including
those expressed herein, those necessarily appurtenant thereto, and those now
hereafter granted municipalities by the Constitution and laws of Oklahoma.
Section 9.
The City of Waurika shall succeed to, own, possess and control all books,
records, documents, and other property, real and personal and otherwise, and
all those in action and claims belonging to and possessed by the City of
Waurika prior to and at the time this Charter shall become effective, and shall
be subject to and liable for all legal debts, judgments, warrants and bonds for
which said City is legally bound at the time this Charter becomes effective.
Section 10.
All valid existing ordinances of this City not inconsistent with this Charter
or inapplicable under the altered form of government provided by the Charter
shall continue in full force until altered, amended, or repealed by the
legislative authority of said City, or until they expire by their own
limitations. No existing right, action, suit, proceeding or contract shall be
affected by this change of the City to a Charter form of government, but shall
continue as if no change had taken place; and all debts, penalties and
forfeitures which have accrued or may hereafter accrue by virtue of anything
heretofore done or commitment heretofore made shall inure to the City's
benefit, and may be sued for and recovered by the City as though no change had
been made in the City's form of government. Nothing herein shall legalize or
validate any illegal, invalid or unauthorized indebtedness of the City
heretofore contracted or incurred or attempted to be incurred, or impair any
defense of the City against the same. The adoption of this Charter shall in no
way interfere with any proceedings heretofore instituted relative to the levy
and collection of taxes and special assessments and levies of all kinds. All
valid and legal contracts and obligations heretofore entered into by the City
shall remain full force and effect and shall be completed and performed under
ordinances and laws existing prior to and at the time this Charter becomes
effective.
Article III
Section 11.
There is reserved to the City of Waurika power to enact ordinances for the
protection of life, health, safety, peace and property, and to safeguard the
welfare of its inhabitants; to define, declare, prohibit, abate and remove
nuisances; to bring actions in the proper courts to restrain and abate
nuisances; to preserve and enforce good order and good government, and provide
for the general welfare and security of the City and its inhabitants; and to
promote the public health, public peace, public morals, public safety and trade
and commerce, and general welfare of the City's inhabitants.
Section 12.
The Board of City Commissioners is authorized to provide penalties for
violations or ordinances of the City, such penalties to be fines or
imprisonment or both, and may provide for commitment to prison in default of
the payment of any such fine and costs. Any person sentenced to imprisonment
under the laws of the City, or committed to prison for failure to pay a fine
and costs or either, may be compelled to work on the streets, alleys and public
grounds of the City, at such rate as the Board of City Commissioners may
determine, until such fine and costs are paid.
Article IV
Section 13.
The legislative powers and authority of the City of Waurika shall be vested in
a Board of City Commissioners. This Board shall consist of five qualified
electors of said City. At the first election of officers under this Charter,
five City Commissioners shall be elected for terms as provided in
section 78 of this Charter. At each annual City election thereafter, one City
Commissioner shall be elected for a term of three years. Each City Commissioner
shall subscribe the oath of office required by the Constitution of this State.
Section 14.
The Board of City Commissioners shall elect one of its members to be Mayor of
the City, and another member to be Vice-Mayor. The Mayor shall preside at
meetings of the Board, and in his official capacity shall sign all ordinances,
resolutions, orders, minutes and proceedings of the Board, all bonds issued by
the City, and such other documents as the Board may authorize or direct him to
sign. He shall perform all other acts and have all other authority given by the
law of the State to the principal officer of a City except where such authority
and power to act is given by this Charter to the City Manager or to some other
person or officer. He shall be the City's Chief Officer for all ceremonial
purposes. For military purposes the Mayor shall be recognized by the Governor
of the State as the City's Principal Officer. In time of emergency or great
public danger, to be determined by the Board of City Commissioners, the Mayor
may take command of the police and maintain order and take necessary action for
the protection of the public safety. In case of the Mayor's resignation, death,
inability to act, or absence, his duties shall be performed by the Vice-Mayor.
Section 15.
The Board of City Commissioners shall hold regular meetings at least once in
each month, on regular dates to be fixed by resolution, for the transaction of
the City's business, and such special meetings as may be called. Special
meetings of the Board may be called by the Mayor, or by any two members of the
Board, with written notice at least four hours before the time of meeting to be
given all Board members not joining in the call. All meetings of the Board
shall be held in the usual meeting place in the City's building, and shall be
open to the public.
Section 16.
No ordinance, resolution, or other action of the Board shall be effective until
approved by a majority vote of all of the members of the Board. All ordinances
and resolutions shall be read in full before they are considered by the Board
for adoption. Except as may be required by law or this Charter for the
publication of ordinances relating to particular matters, ordinances passed by
the Board need not be published in full, but a publication of the title and a
brief summary of the ordinances shall be sufficient. No ordinance shall become
effective until thirty (30) days after its passage and publication, except
ordinances for appropriation of money to pay current expenses of the City
government; provided, that, if the Commissioners shall enact as a part of an
ordinance that an emergency exists and that the preservation of public peace,
health and safety requires that the ordinance be in effect immediately upon its
passage and publication, it shall be in effect when passed by the Board and
published.
Section 17.
The Board of City Commissioners by ordinance may adopt by reference codes,
ordinances and standards relating to building, plumbing, electrical
installations, milk and milk products, and other matters which it has power to
regulate otherwise. Such a code, ordinance or standard so adopted need not be
enrolled in the Book of Ordinances; but a copy shall be filed and kept in the
Office of the City Clerk. The City Clerk shall keep copies of every such code,
ordinance or standard in force for distribution or sale at their approximate
cost.
Section 18.
The ordinances of the City shall be codified and published in book or pamphlet
form at least every ten (10) years. Titles, enacting clauses and emergency
sections may be omitted from the Code; and temporary and special ordinances and
parts of ordinances may be omitted. Permanent general ordinances and parts of
ordinances which are to be repealed by the Code, shall be omitted from the
Code. The ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the Code may be
revised, and the Code may contain new matter, provisions of the State
Constitution and law relating to the City and provisions of this Charter. A
copy of the published Code shall be filed in the Office of the City Clerk, but
the Code need not be enrolled in the Book of Ordinances.
Section 19.
The vote by yeas and nays shall be taken upon all ordinances and resolutions
considered by the Board of Commissioners, and a record of the way each
Commissioner voted shall be entered upon the minutes of the journal.
Section 20.
If any City Commissioner shall be absent from more than one-half (1/2) of all
the meetings of the Board of City Commissioners, regular and special, held
within any period of four (4) consecutive calendar months, he shall thereupon
automatically forfeit his office.
Section 21.
The Commissioners shall receive no compensation for their service.
Section 22.
The salaries and wages of all employees of the City not otherwise provided for
in this Charter shall be fixed and regulated by the City Manager, subject to
the approval of the Board of City Commissioners and shall be on the basis of
responsibilities and qualifications required of them. No officer or employee of
the City shall receive additional compensation or service or other thing of
value from the City beyond the salary so fixed. Where surety company bonds are
required of officers or employees, the premiums thereon shall be paid for by
the City. The Board of City Commissioners is authorized to establish civil
service rules for all or any class of the City's employees.
Article V
Section 23.
The Board of City Commissioners shall appoint a City Manager, chosen upon the
basis of executive ability, who shall receive a salary to be fixed by the Board
of City Commissioners and paid from the General Fund of the City or any other
fund legally available. The Manager may be removed at any time by a majority
vote of the Board of City Commissioners. During his tenure of office, he shall
reside within the Independent School District #23, Jefferson County, Oklahoma.
Under the direction of the Board of City Commissioners, the City Manager shall
be the administrative head of the Municipal government, and a full time City
Manager shall devote all of his time to the affairs of the City. Before
assuming his office, the City Manager shall subscribe the official oath
required by law and give to the City such surety company bond as the Board of
City Commissioners may require and approve.
Section 24.
That the City Manager shall be the chief executive officer and head of the
administrative branch of the City government. He shall execute the laws and
ordinances of the City and shall administer the government of the city and
shall be responsible therefore to the Board of City Commissioners.
He shall:
   (a)   Appoint and when necessary for the good of the service, subject to any
civil service ordinances that may be enacted, such police officers as may be
necessary.
   (b)   Appoint, and when necessary for the good of the service, suspend,
demote, or remove all heads of administrative departments and other
administrative officers and employees of the City except as he or the City
Commission by ordinance may authorize the head of a department, an officer
agency to appoint and suspend, demote, or remove subordinates in such
department, office, or agency, subject to such merit system regulations as the
City Commission may ordain.
   (c)   Have and exercise all management, control, and supervision over all
departments of the City government and to exercise all administrative functions
pertaining thereto, except as may be otherwise provided in this Charter.
   (d)   Manage, supervise, and control all public works, utilities, and parks
of the City, and the maintenance, repair, and operation thereof, and to manage,
supervise, and control the maintenance, cleaning, lighting, and improving of
the streets, alleys, sidewalks, bridges, and public grounds of the City, both
within and without the limits of the City except as otherwise herein provided.
   (e)   Attend all meetings of the Board of City Commissioners, and to
recommend to them for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or
expedient.
   (f)   Prepare and submit to the Board of City Commissioners an annual
financial budget.
   (g)   Do and perform such other duties as may be required of him by the
Board of City Commissioners.
Section 25.
In case of the absences or disability of the City Manager, or a vacancy in the
Office of City Manager, the Board of City Commissioners shall appoint an acting
City Manager to serve during such temporary absence, disability, or vacancy. In
case of permanent vacancy in such office, the Board of City Commissioners shall
fill the office by appointment within one hundred-twenty (120) days after such
vacancy occurs.
Section 26.
The administrative affairs of the City shall be arranged into a Police
Department, a Health Department, a Fire Department, a Water and Sewer
Department, a Street Department, and such other departments as the Board of
City Commissioners may by ordinance prescribe.
   (a)   The Police Department shall consist of such police officers as may be
employed by the City; and from among them the City Manager may designate one to
be the Chief of Police.
   (b)   The Health Department shall consist of a Health Officer, and any other
employees that may be necessary.
   (c)   The Fire Department shall consist of the organized fire company of the
City, with Department Chief and drivers and other firemen, volunteer or
salaried or both.
   (d)   The Water and Sewer Department shall consist of a Superintendent and
such other employees as may be necessary.
   (e)   Other departments which may be prescribed by the Board of City
Commissioners shall consist of such employees as may be necessary.
   (f)   Any person employed in the service of the City in any department
shall, at the discretion of the City Manager, render services for the City in
any other department when directed to do so by the City Manager.
Section 27.
None of the City Commissioners shall recommend any appointment to be made by
the City Manager, except on the specific request made by the Manager to the
Board of City Commissioners in open session. Any Commissioner violating this
section shall forfeit his office.
Section 28.
Neither the City Manager, the Board of City Commissioners, nor any other
authority of the City government, may appoint or select any person related to
himself, or to the City Manager or any Commissioner, or, in the case of plural
authority, to one of its members, by blood or marriage within the third degree,
to any office or employment in the City government.
Section 29.
Except as may be otherwise provided by this Charter or by ordinance, the same
person may hold more than one office or position in the City government. The
City Manager may hold more than one such office or position, through
appointment by himself or through appointment or election by the Board of City
Commissioners or other City authority having authority to fill the particular
office or position, subject to any regulations which the Board of City
Commissioners may make by ordinance; but he may not receive compensation for
services in such other offices and position.
Section 30.
No City Commissioner may be appointed City Manager during the term for which he
shall have been elected or appointed, or within six (6) years after said City
Commissioner leaves office.
Section 31.
There shall be a City Clerk of the City of Waurika, who shall be appointed by
and hold office at the pleasure of the City Manager. The City Clerk shall have
all the powers and duties prescribed by law and by ordinance, except as may be
otherwise provided in this Charter. He shall collect all revenues, fees and
other moneys due the City and deposit them daily in such banks as may be
designated by the Board of City Commissioners. He shall have custody of and be
responsible for all books, records, maps and other documents and papers
belonging to the City where the custody is not given by law to some other
officer or person. He shall also perform all duties that may be required of him
by ordinances of the City enacted after the adoption of this Charter. Before
entering upon his duties, he shall give to the City such surety company bond as
may be required by the Board of City Commissioners, conditioned that he will
faithfully perform his duties and account for all money and other property of
the City for which he is chargeable.
Section 32.
Immediately after the close of every month's business, the City Clerk shall
prepare and keep on file in his office for inspection by the public a complete
financial operating report, which shall show by classifications the gross
earnings, the operating expenses, and the net profit or the net expense of each
department, and a combined operating report of all departments collectively,
and a balance sheet showing all assets and liabilities of the City. The forms
for such reports and balance sheets, and the items to be contained therein, may
be prescribed by resolution enacted by the Board of City Commissioners. Such
reports and balance sheets shall be made monthly, beginning not later than the
first day of July next following the taking office by the first City
Commissioners under this Charter.
Section 33.
The Board of City Commissioners shall provide for and require an annual audit
by a qualified accountant.
Section 34.
The duties prescribed by law and those usually pertaining to the Office of the
City Treasurer shall be performed by the City Manager, except that the Board of
City Commissioners may by ordinance provide for a different officer to be
appointed by such Board to be City Treasurer and perform the duties of that
office. The Board of City Commissioners may, at its' discretion, directly
appoint an individual to the office of the City Treasurer without first
amending any existing ordinance. The Board of City Commissioners may remove the
City Treasurer from office for the good of the service. The Treasurer shall
keep the funds of the City in depositories designated by the Board of City
Commissioners; and, except sinking funds and except in cases for which a
different provision is made in this Charter, he shall pay out of the funds of
the City only in payment of claims against the City, verified by affidavit,
which have been allowed by the Board of City Commissioners, in a regular or a
special meeting, such allowance to be endorsed upon the claim and signed by the
Mayor. It is not required that warrants be issued to authorize payment of such
allowed claims.
Section 35.
The City Manager, subject to any regulations which the Board of City
Commissioners may prescribe, shall contract for and purchase, or issue purchase
orders for, all supplies, materials and equipment for offices, departments, and
agencies of the city government. The Board of City Commissioners shall by
ordinance, which may be amended from time to time, set the dollar amount of
every such contract or purchase, which may be made by the City Manager, before
requiring the prior approval of the City Commission. In no event may the City
Manager make purchases or contracts as herein provided in excess of the dollar
amount provided for by the then existing ordinance. The City Manager also may
transfer to or between offices, departments, and agencies, or sell, surplus or
obsolete supplies, materials, and equipment subject to such regulations as the
Board of City Commissioners may prescribe.
Section 36.
   (a)   The City Manager, subject to any regulations which the council may
prescribe, shall contract for the purchase, or issue purchase authorizations
for, all supplies, materials and equipment for the offices, departments, and
agencies of the city government. Every such contract or purchase exceeding an
amount to be established by ordinance, shall require the prior approval of the
council. The City manager also may transfer to or between offices, departments,
and agencies, or sell, surplus or obsolete supplies, materials, and equipment,
subject to such regulations as the council may prescribe.
   (b)   Before the purchase of, or contract for, any supplies, materials or
equipment, or the sale of any surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or
equipment, ample opportunity for competitive bidding, under such regulations,
and with such exceptions, as the council may prescribe shall be given; but the
council shall not except a particular contract, purchase, or sale from the
requirement of competitive bidding; and
   (c)   The council by ordinance may transfer some or all the power granted to
the City Manager by this section, relating to purchases and sales, to an
officer appointed by and subordinate to the City Manager.
Section 37.
No contract shall be entered into on behalf of the City to expend any money of
the City until an appropriation has been made for that purpose, nor in any
amount in excess of the unencumbered balance of such appropriation, or from the
proceeds of a bond issue.
Section 38.
Before any City funds are placed in any depository, the Board of City
Commissioners shall require from the depository such security as shall be
sufficient, in the opinion of the Board, to protect the City's deposits;
provided, that, no additional security shall be required if the City's funds in
any given depository do not exceed the amount protected by the Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation Act.
Section 39.
There shall be a City Attorney who shall be legal advisor to the City
Commissioners and the City Manager, and perform those duties assigned by the
general laws of Oklahoma to City Attorneys. He shall represent the City in all
actions and proceedings in all courts. He shall be appointed by the Board of
City Commissioners, shall hold office at their pleasure, and shall receive such
compensation as they shall determine.
Article VI
Section 40.
No franchise or right to use or occupy any street or other public place in the
City of Waurika shall be granted, extended or renewed except in conformity with
the Constitution of Oklahoma and the ordinances that have been and may
hereafter be enacted by the City; and no public service utility franchise shall
be granted, extended or renewed until it is authorized by a majority of the
electors voting thereon at a general election or at a special election called
for that purpose as provided by law.
Article VII
Section 41.
All laws of the State of Oklahoma pertaining to revenue and fiscal management
of cities, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter, are hereby
made applicable to the City of Waurika.
Section 42.
Sections 9, 10, 26 and 27 of article 10 of the Constitution of Oklahoma, as
amended, and the general laws of Oklahoma vitalizing those sections of the
Constitution are hereby made applicable to the City of Waurika.
Article VIII
Section 43.
There shall be in the City of Waurika a Municipal Court. The City Manager shall
appoint a Municipal Judge, who shall preside over the Municipal Court, and who
shall hold office at the pleasure of the City Manager. Such Municipal Court and
the Judge thereof shall be vested with all power and authority conferred on
police courts and Municipal courts and the Judges thereof by the laws of
Oklahoma and the Charter and ordinances of the City of Waurika.
Section 44.
Such Municipal Court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction of all criminal
proceedings for violations of the ordinances of the City and shall also have
all power and jurisdiction now conferred on police courts and Municipal courts
by the Constitution and general laws of Oklahoma.
Section 45.
There shall be no trial by jury in said Municipal Court, and no change of venue
therefrom. From any judgment in any criminal proceeding in said Municipal
Court, the defendant shall have an absolute right of appeal to the County Court
of Jefferson County, Oklahoma, in the manner now provided by the general laws
of the State for appeals from Municipal courts and police courts.
Section 46.
The Judge of said Municipal Court is authorized to administer oaths. The said
court is empowered to punish for contempt, enforce its judgments, mandates and
orders, punish by fine and imprisonment the violations of the ordinances of the
City, and to reprimand, parole and remit the punishment of defendants; and it
may provide for separate detention of juvenile offenders, and may exercise
jurisdiction to try juvenile offenders and punish them in cases where exclusive
jurisdiction therefore is not conferred by law upon some other court.
Section 47.
All fines, penalties and forfeitures collected by the Municipal Court or the
Judge thereof shall be the property of the City of Waurika, and shall be paid
over to the City Clerk periodically as the Board of City Commissioners may
provide; except that, until otherwise provided by City ordinance, the Judge of
the Municipal Court shall retain from the costs collected by him in each
criminal case the police Judge fee which is provided by Ordinance no. 26 of the
City of Waurika, approved February 11, 1913.
Article IX
Section 48.
The election of all officers under this Charter shall be nonpartisan.
Section 49.
The election of all City Commissioners shall be at large, and not from wards or
other subdivisions of the City.
Section 50.
Electors shall possess the same qualification as are required by the general
laws of Oklahoma.
Section 51.
   (a)   A general election shall be held in the City of Waurika for among
other things, the election of a City Commissioner or City Commissioners, on the
first Tuesday in April. The general election shall be held on the first Tuesday
in April in accordance with the laws of the State of Oklahoma.
   (b)   The provisions of the State Constitution and laws of the State of
Oklahoma relating to elections shall govern every election of whatever kind of
this City insofar as they are applicable and are not superseded by the Amended
Charter or by ordinance.
   (c)   All city elections shall be conducted on a non-partisan basis.
   (d)   All citizens legally registered under the constitution and laws of the
State of Oklahoma to vote in the City shall be registered voters of the City
within the meaning of this Charter.
   (e)   The filing period for Regular Municipal Elections shall begin at 8:00
a.m. on the first Monday in February and end at 5:00 p.m. on the following
Wednesday.
   (f)   Candidates for municipal offices shall file Declarations of Candidacy
with the Secretary of the County Election Board.
   (g)   Any candidate may withdraw his candidacy only by filing a written
notice of withdrawal with the Secretary of the County Election Board no later
than 5:00 p.m. on Friday following the close of the filing period.
   (h)   The County Election Board shall certify results of any municipal
elections to the governing board of the municipality for which the election was
held. Certificates of Election shall be issued to the successful candidates by
the County Election Board in the same manner as is prescribed for County
Officers.
   (i)   Absentee voting is authorized for any elections conducted by a County
Election Board and absentee ballots must be provided. Absentee voting is
required in cities with home rule charters. Any registered voter may apply for
an absentee ballot for any election in which he is eligible to vote.
Section 52.
Deleted by vote on April 14, 1998.
Section 53.
Deleted by vote on April 14, 1998.
Section 54.
Female electors as provided by the Constitution of Oklahoma, shall be eligible
to vote in all City elections, and to hold any office, elective or appointive,
created by this Charter. (5-1-1951)
Section 55.
A vacancy in office shall exist when any elective officer fails to qualify and
assume his office within twenty (20) days after the time provided for him to
assume his office, and when an officer or officer-elect dies, removes from the
City, if convicted of a felony, or becomes otherwise legally disqualified to
hold the office. Vacancies in elective offices shall be filled by appointment
by the Board of City Commissioners until the next City general election, at
which time an officer shall be elected for any remaining portion of the
unexpired term.
Section 56.
The Board of City Commissioners is given power to pass all ordinances that may
be deemed necessary to fully vitalize all provisions of this Charter pertaining
to elections.
Section 57.
Article XVIII of the Constitution of Oklahoma is adopted, ratified, and made to
be in full force and effect for the government of the City of Waurika.
Article X
Section 58.
The Board of City Commissioners may provide by ordinance for a Library Board to
have control and management of any library owned by the City and may provide
financial support for such library from City funds.
Section 59.
The Board of City Commissioners may provide by ordinance for a Cemetery Board
to have control and management of any cemetery owned by the City.
Section 60.
All parks and recreational grounds and facilities owned by the City or under
its control, within and without the City, shall be under the management and
control of the City Manager, subject to such limitations as the Board of City
Commissioners may establish.
Article XI
Section 61.
The City of Waurika shall have the power to construct or cause to be
constructed special improvements, including street curbing, guttering, grading,
surface drainage, drainage by storm sewers, storm sewer drainage constructed
separately from paving, paving, and otherwise surfacing of streets, alleys and
other public places and ways, sanitary sewer systems, and street lighting.
Proceedings for the installation of any such improvements and proceedings to
provide for the payment of the same shall be governed by the general laws of
Oklahoma pertaining to cities.
Article XII
Section 62.
The Board of City Commissioners shall require good and sufficient corporate
surety bonds from all contractors.
Section 63.
All contracts pertaining to public improvements, and maintenance of public
property, involving an expenditure of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or more,
shall be based upon specifications which have been submitted to and approved by
the Board of City Commissioners. Upon approval of such specifications the Board
shall advertise for bids, either sealed bids or open competitive oral bids as
the Board may elect, for the proposed work or matter embraced in the
specifications, such advertisement to be published in a newspaper having
general circulation in the City. If the advertisement calls for sealed bids,
they shall be filed with the City Clerk. The Board shall receive the bids,
either sealed or oral open bids as the case may be, in open session, and
tabulate the same; and may thereafter award the contract to the lowest
responsible bidder who, in the judgment of the Board, can and will fully
perform such contract in a manner satisfactory to the City.
Section 64.
No officer or employee of the City shall give or promise any valuable thing to
any person in consideration of being appointed or selected to any office or
place of employment with the City; and any person violating the provision of
this section shall thereafter forever be disqualified from holding any office
or employment with the City.
Section 65.
No officer of the City shall accept any donation of gratuity of any kind,
directly or indirectly, from any subordinate or employee or from any applicant
for any position of employment with the City; and any person violating the
provisions of this section shall thereafter forever be disqualified from
holding any office or employment with the City.
Section 66.
No officer or employee of the City (except members of the Fire Department not
employed full time by the City) shall be directly or indirectly in the employ
of any person, company or corporation holding or seeking to hold any franchise
from the City, or shall receive directly or indirectly any wages, commissions,
gifts or other things of value from any such person, company or corporation;
and any person violating the provisions of this section shall thereafter
forever be disqualified from holding any office or employment with the City.
Section 67.
Neither the City Manager nor any member of the Board of City Commissioners nor
any other officer of said City, elective or appointive, shall be financially
interested, directly or indirectly, in any work, business or contract which is
to be paid for with money of the City or by any assessment levied by ordinance
or resolution of the Board of City Commissioners. Any contract that is
violative of this section is declared to be illegal and void.
Section 68.
Every officer of the City, elective or appointive, who shall approve, allow, or
pay any claim or demand on the City Treasury which is not authorized by law or
which is forbidden by law, shall be liable to the City individually and on his
official bond for the amount so illegally approved, allowed or paid.
Section 69.
All writs and other process issued out of the Municipal Court shall run in the
name of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma, and shall be signed by the Judge; and
they may be served by any police officer of the City or by any other person
designated by the Judge of the Court by written endorsement upon the writ.
Section 70.
The City shall have and exercise general power and control over its streets,
alleys and other public places, and its public property, and may by ordinance
or otherwise prescribe rules for the use, preservation, and protection thereof.
Section 71.
The Board of City Commissioners shall cause to be prepared and published an
annual financial statement showing all receipts and expenditures by departments
of the City government.
Section 72.
The enumeration of powers reserved to this Charter by the City of Waurika shall
not be held or construed to limit the general powers of the City or to exclude
any powers not herein enumerated; for it is intended by the adoption of this
Charter to reserve to and confer upon the City and its inhabitants full and
unrestricted rights, powers, and privileges of local self- government, limited
only by the applicable parts of the Constitution of Oklahoma.
Article XIII
Section 73.
The rates charged by the City for utility services furnished by the City, shall
be fixed by the Board of City Commissioners by resolution, and may be changed
by such Board from time to time.
Section 74.
Beginning not later than July 1, 1953, a minimum of six percent (6%) of the
gross receipts of the City from the sale of water and water service shall be
placed each month in the sinking fund depository of the City and credited to
the City's fund which is reserved for the payment of the City's bonded
indebtedness and the interest thereon, and this shall continue at all times
when there shall be any unpaid water bonds of the City outstanding, either
bonds of past or future issues. At such times as there shall be no unpaid water
bonds of the City outstanding, the said six percent (6%) of the water receipts
shall be placed in a special fund of the City to be used for such machinery
replacement and distribution system extensions in the Water Department as the
Board of City Commissioners may deem necessary, and shall be used for no other
purpose.
Article XIV
Section 75.
The Mayor, the City Manager and the City Clerk, and such other officers as the
Board of City Commissioners may by ordinance designate, are authorized to
administer oaths.
Section 76.
This Charter may be amended by proposal submitted by the Board of City
Commissioners or by proposal initiated by petition, in either event subject to
ratification by a majority of the qualified electors voting thereon at an
election, and approval by the Governor of Oklahoma, all as provided by the laws
of Oklahoma pertaining to cities.
Article XV
Section 77.
The provisions of this Charter relating to the election of the Board of City
Commissioners shall take effect for that purpose immediately upon its adoption
by the electors of the City and its approval by the Governor of the State. The
entire Charter shall become effective, and the government provided by it shall
be inaugurated, at the time prescribed below for the first meeting of the Board
of City Commissioners.
Section 78.
Within ten (10) days after the approval of this Charter by the Governor, the
Mayor of the City of Waurika shall issue a proclamation calling an election in
said City on a date to be fixed by the proclamation not less than twenty (20)
nor more than thirty (30) days from its date; and notice of such election shall
be given by publication of the election proclamation in at least two (2) issues
of a weekly newspaper published in said City. The manner of candidates filing
for such election, and the manner of conducting such election shall all be
governed by the appropriate provisions of this Charter. At such election there
shall be elected three (3) City Commissioners for terms ending on the first
Monday in May in the years 1952, 1953, 1954, respectively, or when their
successors are lawfully elected and qualified. They shall hold their first
meeting and be inducted into office at noon on the first Monday following their
election. (5-1-1951)

CERTIFICATE
   Whereas, a duly constituted Board of Freeholders of the City of Waurika,
Oklahoma, prepared and returned the Charter of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma,
as it appears hereinbefore;
   Whereas, the electors of the City of Waurika, at an election held on April
27, 1951, duly ratified said Charter; and
   Whereas, I have examined said Charter and find that it is not in conflict
with the Constitution and laws of the State of Oklahoma;
   Therefore, I, Johnston Murray, Governor of the State of Oklahoma, do hereby
approve the said Charter of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma, as it appears
hereinbefore.

Oklahoma and direct the Secretary of State to attest this certificate and affix
to it the Great Seal of the State of Oklahoma, this the 1st day of May, 1951.

APPROVAL BY GOVERNOR OF AMENDED MUNICIPAL CHARTER
   I, Frank Keating, Governor of the State of Oklahoma, pursuant to the powers
vested in me by Article 18 of the Constitution of the State of Oklahoma and the
provisions of Section 13-111 of Title 11 of the Oklahoma Statutes proclaim the
following:
1.   On February 16, 1998, The City Council of the City of Waurika, Jefferson
County, State of Oklahoma, by resolution directed a proposition to be included
on the ballot of the Special Election conducted for the purpose of submitting
to the qualified thereof, amendments to the Waurika Charter.
2.   The amendments to Section 24, 25, 30, 34, 35, and 36 of Article 5 and
Section 51, 52, and 53 of Article 10 of the Charter of the City of Waurika,
Oklahoma, submitted to the vote on April 14, 1998, have been duly adopted
pursuant to the laws of Oklahoma.
3.   The Certificate of Authentication of the election certifies that said
propositions were approved by a majority of those electors voting in the
election and that the Amendments to the Charter were approved as required by
Section 13-111 of Title 11 of the Oklahoma Statutes.
THEREFORE, I find that the amendments are not in conflict with the Constitution
or laws of the State of Oklahoma and hereby approve the adopted amendments to
be in full force and effect as provided by law.
A copy of this executive order shall be forwarded to the Mayor of the City of
Waurika.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and caused the Great Seal of
the State of Oklahoma to be affixed at Oklahoma City, this 8th day of December
1998.
                  BY THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA
                   /s/ Frank Keating

/s/ Tom Cole
TOM COLE
SECRETARY OF STATE
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
WAURIKA CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title; Authority
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Jurisdiction Outside Corporate Limits
1-1-5: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE; AUTHORITY:
Upon the adoption by the Board of City Commissioners, this Code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official City Code of
Waurika. This Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the WAURIKA CITY
CODE and is hereby published by authority of the City Commission and 11
Oklahoma Statutes sections 14-108 and 14-109, and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the City as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this Code by title in any legal documents. (2019 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of the
State as the ordinances of the City of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2019 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this Code.
(2019 Code)
1-1-4: JURISDICTION OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
   A.   All provisions of this Code, and other ordinances of the City now in
effect or adopted in the future, are hereby extended to all real property
belonging to, or under the control of, the City outside the corporate limits of
the City, and shall be in full force and effect thereon insofar as they are
applicable.
   B.   Any words in any such provision indicating that its effect is limited
to the corporate limits of the City shall be deemed to mean and include also
such outlying real property belonging to, or under the control of, the City,
unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.
   C.   The operation of motor vehicles and other traffic upon roads, streets
and highways that form the corporate boundary line of the City shall be subject
to all Municipal Traffic Ordinances and other ordinances of the City. (2007
Code § 8-13)
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any
part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof,
or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause
the law of the City to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this
section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed the limits set out in section
1-10-21 of this title. (2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Court Proceedings
1-2-3: Enumeration Of State Law Or Local Provisions
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the City passed prior to the adoption of this Code
are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Code or are by
necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: (2019 Code)
   A.   Ordinances promising, obligating or guaranteeing the payment of money
for or to the City authorizing the issuance of any Municipal bonds or any
evidence of the City's indebtedness.
   B.   Appropriation Ordinances, or ordinances providing for: 1) the levy of
taxes; 2) an annual budget; 3) a special election; or 4) prescribing salaries
for City officers and employees.
   C.   Ordinances which provide for the annexation or de- annexation of
territory to or from the City.
   D.   Ordinances approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to, any
contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument, or granting any
franchise.
   E.   Ordinances authorizing or relating to specific public improvements.
   F.   Ordinances vacating, opening or dedicating specific streets and alleys.
   G.   Ordinances relating to specific street improvements and assessments.
   H.   Ordinances relating to the grade or alignment of specific streets.
   I.   Ordinances naming or renaming specific streets.
   J.   Ordinances granting railroads or others the right to use specific
streets, alleys or rights-of-way.
   K.   Ordinances changing the zoning district classification of a specific
parcel of real property.
   L.   Other temporary or special ordinances. (2007 Code § 8-10)
1-2-2: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts:
      1.   Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall
affect any offense or act committed or done, any penalty or forfeiture
incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the
effective date of this Code. (2007 Code § 8-12)
      2.   No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former
ordinance whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any
offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any
penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim
arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such
offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
      3.   The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force
before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the City herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the City under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this Code. (2019 Code)
1-2-3: ENUMERATION OF STATE LAW OR LOCAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   State Law:
      1.   Provisions of State law which affect the City, because of its
general relationship to the State, may not be enumerated herein, but may be
adopted by reference as inseparable parts of this Code.
      2.   Provisions of State law which prescribe specific actions or laws for
the City and its citizens may be included in this Code for purposes of clarity.
      3.   Provisions of State law in matters of wider public concern which are
not enumerated herein, but which affect the City and its citizens in a general
way, may not be enumerated herein, but may nevertheless be made a part of this
Code through adoption by reference.
   B.   Local Provisions: All provisions which are of purely local concern may
be specifically enumerated in this Code. The regulations, rules, prohibitions,
nuisances, offenses and other provisions which are of purely local concern, as
provided by State law, and are specifically enumerated herein in detail, shall
be enforced by the City; duly authorized officers and agents of the City shall
have all powers, duties and responsibilities necessary to enforce the same.
(2007 Code § 8-11)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
   A.   It is hereby declared to be the intention of the City Commission that
the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code, or any
codes or portions of codes adopted herein, are severable, and if any phrase,
clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this Code or any code adopted
herein, or of any ordinance in this Code shall be declared unconstitutional,
illegal or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of
competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect
any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of
this Code, or of any codes or portions of codes adopted herein. (2007 Code § 8-
16; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Further, if any word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of
this Code shall seem invalid through printing or typographical error, such
error or misprint shall not serve to misconstrue or invalidate the intent
thereof, nor affect in any way the intent or validity of any or all other
words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code. (2007
Code § 8-16)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words; Interpretations
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS; INTERPRETATIONS:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the Mayor and City Commission may be fully
carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other City officer to do some act or perform some
duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other
officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   D.   Gender: The use of any gender based pronoun should not be construed to
be gender biased, but is only used for grammatical simplicity.
   E.   Joint Authority: All words giving joint authority to three (3) or more
persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority
of such persons or officers.
   F.   Law: Includes applicable Federal law, provisions of the Constitution
and Statutes of the State of Oklahoma, the ordinances of the City, and, when
appropriate, any and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   G.   May/Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is mandatory.
   H.   Or/And: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the
sense requires it.
   I.   Preceding, Following: The next before and next after, respectively.
   J.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases which are not
specifically defined shall be construed according to the common and accepted
usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may
have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and
understood according to such meaning.
   K.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. Words
used in the plural number may also include the singular unless a contrary
intention plainly appears.
   L.   Officers, Employees, Agencies Generally: Whenever any officer,
employee, agency or department is referred to by title only, such reference
shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Waurika".
   M.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   N.   Statutory References: Reference to the Statutes of the State of
Oklahoma means the statutes as they now are or as they may be amended to be.
   O.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the City
has been changed in the content of this Code to "title", "chapter", "section"
and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to the City's ordinances is not meant
to amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2019 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
CITY: The City of Waurika, County of Jefferson, State of Oklahoma. The word
"City" shall be construed as if the words "of Waurika, Oklahoma", followed.
CODE: The City Code of the City of Waurika.
COMMISSION, CITY COMMISSION, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS: The Board of Commissioners
of Waurika.
COUNTY: The County of Jefferson, Oklahoma.
OS: Oklahoma Statutes.
PERSON: Shall extend, and be applied to, associations, corporations, firms,
partnerships and bodies politic and corporate, as well as to individuals.
Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the word "person", applied to
partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners and members thereof, and
as applied to corporations, the officers thereof.
STATE OR THE STATE: The State of Oklahoma. (2019 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (2019
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty; Judicial Review
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY; JUDICIAL REVIEW:
   A.   Whenever, in this Code or any ordinance of the City, an act is
prohibited, is made or declared to be unlawful, an offense or misdemeanor, or
wherever in this Code the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do
any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided
therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or of any such
ordinance shall be punishable by a fine in any amount not exceeding the limits
established in section
1-10-21 of this title. Each day on which any violation of this Code or of any
ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such.
   B.   No penalty imposed by, and pursuant to, this Code shall interfere with
the right of the City also to apply to the proper courts of the State for a
mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against such person, firm
or corporation. (2007 Code § 8-50)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this Code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this Code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2019 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the City Commissioners to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2019 Code)
CHAPTER 5
WARDS AND BOUNDARIES
SECTION:
1-5-1: Municipal Wards; Annexations
1-5-2: Corporate Boundaries Map
1-5-3: Zoning District Boundaries Map
1-5-1: MUNICIPAL WARDS; ANNEXATIONS:
   A.   When new territory is annexed to the City, it shall become a part of
the ward or wards to which it is adjacent. The streets, boulevards and avenues
named shall be extended north, south, east and west, as the case may be, as
ward boundaries, as new territory is annexed at the points where said streets,
boulevards and avenues touch the City limits, so that the extensions of said
streets, boulevards and avenues shall become a part of the ward boundaries of
territory annexed adjacent thereto.
   B.   References to streets, boulevards and avenues shall mean the
centerlines thereof. (2007 Code § 20-1)
1-5-2: CORPORATE BOUNDARIES MAP:
   A.   A map depicting the current corporate boundaries of the City shall be
maintained and displayed in the Office of the City Clerk.
   B.   This map shall reflect all current Annexation and De-Annexation
Ordinances and orders, all plat and/or street vacation orders, and all official
street names and shall represent the official map of the corporate boundaries
of the City.
   C.   This map may be combined with the official Zoning Districts Map as
provided for in section
1-5-3 of this chapter. All dedicated streets and alleys shall be shown on this
map; vacated streets and alleys shall not be shown on said map, but shall be
redrawn by the methods provided by Oklahoma Statutes.
   D.   This map shall be available for public inspection. (2007 Code § 20-10)
1-5-3: ZONING DISTRICT BOUNDARIES MAP:
   A.   A map showing the boundaries of all current zoning districts within the
entire corporate boundaries of the City shall be maintained in the Office of
the City Clerk, if a Zoning Ordinance is in effect within the City.
   B.   This map shall reflect all current Zoning Ordinance provisions and all
current ordinances rezoning land, and shall represent the official Zoning
Districts Map for the City.
   C.   This map may be combined with the official map of the corporate limits
of the City as provided for in section
1-5-1 of this chapter.
   D.   This map shall be available for public inspection. (2007 Code § 20-20)
CHAPTER 6
INCORPORATION; FORM OF GOVERNMENT
SECTION:
1-6-1: Incorporation
1-6-2: Form Of Government
1-6-3: General Powers Of City
1-6-4: Succession In Government
1-6-1: INCORPORATION:
The City, within the corporate limits as now established or as hereafter may be
established, shall continue to be a Municipal body politic and corporate in
perpetuity under the name of the "City of Waurika, Oklahoma". It shall succeed
to and possess all the property, rights, privileges, franchises, powers and
immunities now belonging to the corporation known as the City of Waurika,
Oklahoma, and shall be liable for all debts and other obligations for which the
corporation is now legally bound. (2007 Code § 1-1)
1-6-2: FORM OF GOVERNMENT:
The Municipal government provided for the City shall be the "Board of City
Commissioners - City Manager" form of government, as outlined in the Waurika
City Charter. All powers of the City shall be exercised in the manner
prescribed by the City Charter, this Code, future ordinances or State law;
provided, that, this Code and all future ordinances are not repugnant to the
State Constitution and laws. (2007 Code § 1-2)
1-6-3: GENERAL POWERS OF CITY:
   A.   The City shall have all the powers, functions, rights, privileges,
franchises and immunities specifically granted to municipalities, or not
prohibited by the State Constitution and laws, and all the implied power
necessary to carry into execution all the powers granted.
   B.   The City shall have the power to adopt a Corporate Seal and alter the
same, to sue and be sued, to make contracts and to grant, extend and renew
franchises. It shall have the power, in accordance with the State Constitution
and laws, to accept and administer Federal and State grants in aid. It shall
have the power to ordain and enforce local legislation, consistent with the
State Constitution and laws, for the proper organization and functioning of
Municipal government, for the preservation and enforcement of good government
and order, for the protection of health, life, peace, safety, morals and
property, for the prevention, summary abatement and removal of nuisances, and
otherwise for the promotion of the common welfare.
   C.   The enumeration of particular powers of this Code shall not be deemed
to be exclusive or limiting. In addition to the powers enumerated herein or
implied hereby, the City shall have all the powers which, under the State
Constitution and laws, it would be competent for this Code specifically to
enumerate. (2007 Code § 1-3)
1-6-4: SUCCESSION IN GOVERNMENT:
   A.   All ordinances, insofar as they are not inconsistent with this Code,
shall continue in effect until they are repealed or until they expire by their
limitations.
   B.   All officers and employees of the City, under any and all previous
ordinances, shall continue in the offices and employments which they
respectively hold, after this Code goes into effect.
   C.   All books, monies or other property belonging to the City, and in
charge or possession of any officer of the City shall be delivered to said
person's successor. (2007 Code § 1-222)
CHAPTER 7
MAYOR AND BOARD OF CITY COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Powers Of Commissioners; Filing Fee For Candidates
1-7-2: Municipal Policy And Business
1-7-3: City Commission Meetings
1-7-4: Removal Of Commissioners; Vacancies
1-7-5: Mayor And Vice Mayor
1-7-6: Ordinances
1-7-1: POWERS OF COMMISSIONERS; FILING FEE FOR CANDIDATES:
   A.   Powers And Authority:
      1.   The legislative powers and authority of the City shall be vested in
a Board of City Commissioners (see
section 13 et seq. of the City Charter).
      2.   Powers of the Board of City Commissioners shall be as established by
the City Charter and this Code; provided, that any provisions in this Code
shall not conflict with the City Charter.
      3.   Except as otherwise provided in the City Charter and this Code, all
powers of the City, including the determination of matters of policy, shall be
vested in the City Commission; said City Commission shall have, and may
utilize, all of the powers granted to the City and said City Commission by the
State Constitution and laws. (2007 Code § 1-11)
   B.   Filing Fee For Candidates: Candidates for the Office of Board of City
Commissioners shall pay a filing fee in the amount of three hundred dollars
($300.00) to the County Election Board when filing for office. The amount of
the filing fee may be increased or decreased by a resolution of the Board of
City Commissioners. (Ord. 04082019-02, 4-8-2019; amd. Ord. 11122019-05, 11-12-
2019)
1-7-2: MUNICIPAL POLICY AND BUSINESS:
   A.   General Policy Concerning Business And Administration: The City
Commission shall conduct all business of the City, set policy for the efficient
administration of City government, administratively supervise all activities or
City employees, and carry out their responsibilities, powers and duties as
officers and as a corporate and politic body, within the limits prescribed by
the State Constitution and laws and the City Charter and this Code.
   B.   Nondiscrimination: It shall be the policy of the City government that
no person shall be discriminated against on the grounds of race, creed, color,
sex, religion, handicap, national origin, age, genetic information, gender
identity or disability, unless the City can demonstrate that accommodation for
the disability would impose an undue hardship on the operation of the business
of the City, in employment or other activities sponsored directly or indirectly
by the City.
   C.   Voting Upon Question; Noninterest: Every member of the City Commission
who shall be present when the opportunity or need arises to vote upon a
question, shall vote thereon, unless said member is directly or indirectly
interested in the question, in which event said interest shall be fully
disclosed to the City Commission and it shall be made a matter of record. (Ord.
11032017-1, 11-6-2017)
1-7-3: CITY COMMISSION MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Municipal business shall be conducted at regularly-
scheduled open and public meetings held in the City Hall (or another agreed
upon place which is open to the public) at least once in each month, on dates
and times as determined by the Board of City Commissioners and fixed by
resolution. Notice of said determination shall be given as required by the
Oklahoma Open Meeting Act, 25 0klahoma Statutes section 301 et seq., as
amended.
   B.   Special Meetings: A special City Commission meeting may be called by
the Mayor, or by any two (2) of the City Commissioners, upon the serving of
public notice of the date, time, and place of the meeting as required by
current State law.
   C.   Emergency Meetings: An emergency meeting may be called by the Mayor, or
by a majority of the City Commissioners. Emergency meetings of the City
Commission may be held without the public notice heretofore required. Should an
emergency meeting be necessary, the person or persons calling such a meeting
shall give as much advance public notice as is reasonable and possible under
the circumstances existing in person or by telephonic or electronic means.
   D.   Meeting Agendas: All items placed on a monthly City Commission meeting
agenda, a special City Commission meeting agenda, or an emergency City
Commission meeting agenda must be done in writing on an agenda form on file in
City Hall. Said agenda form shall be signed and dated with supporting
documentation attached, if any. The agenda item may be placed on said agenda by
the City Manager, any City Commissioner, or the City Attorney if presented to
the City Clerk no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon the Wednesday prior to
the meeting with the exception of a special or emergency meeting when said item
or items will be submitted at the time of the calling and scheduling the
special or emergency meeting. Any other person may be allowed to submit an
agenda item and form, provided it is also signed and approved by the City
Manager, any City Commissioner, or the City Attorney. No person may remove or
deny an item from being placed on the agenda except for tle person having
submitted the item for the agenda, or the City Attorney if he or she deems it
is in violation of City, State, or Federal law, who will also advise that
person if it is removed and why. The exception to submission of a signed agenda
form is for recurring items such as the Treasurer's report, purchase order
printouts, or other financial reports, the City Clerk's report, the Manager's
report, the police report, items which have been tabled to be put on the next
month's agenda, and approval of minutes of a previous meeting.
   E.   Order of Business: The City Commission shall establish, by motion or
resolution, an order of business for the conduct of its meetings.
   F.   All Boards and Meetings of the City of Waurika shall follow
parliamentary procedure known as Robert's Rules of Order, newly revised, and as
may be amended from time to time. (Ord. 010818-01, 1-22-2018; amd. Ord.
2142022-04, 2-14-2022)
1-7-4: REMOVAL OF COMMISSIONERS; VACANCIES:
   A.   Removal Authorized: Any Commissioner, including the Mayor, may be
removed from office for any cause specified by, and using the methods
prescribed and specified by, applicable State law for the removal of officers,
including 22 Oklahoma Statutes section 1181 et seq., as amended.
   B.   Absent From Meetings: Whenever a member of the City Commission is
absent from more than one-half (1/2) of all regular and special meetings of
said City Commission held within any period of four (4) consecutive months,
said person shall thereupon automatically cease to hold office.
   C.   Filling Vacancies: Vacancies in the membership of the City Commission
shall be filled according to article IX of the City Charter. (2007 Code § 1-14)
1-7-5: MAYOR AND VICE MAYOR:
   A.   Election From Commission Members: The Board of City Commissioners shall
elect one of its members as Mayor and one as Vice Mayor. The Mayor shall be
elected annually.
   B.   Vacancy In Office: When a vacancy occurs in the Office of Mayor, the
Board of City Commissioners shall elect another Mayor from among its members to
serve for the duration of the unexpired term.
   C.   Preside At Meetings: The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the
Board of City Commissioners and may call special meetings thereof.
   D.   Duties:
      1.   The Mayor shall certify to the correct enrollment of all ordinances
and resolutions passed by the Board of City Commissioners. The Mayor shall have
all the powers, rights, privileges, duties and responsibilities of a City
Commissioner, and, as an elected representative of the citizens, may vote on
all matters that come before the Board of City Commissioners.
      2.   The Mayor shall perform all other duties prescribed by State law,
City Charter or ordinance.
   E.   Head Of Government For Ceremonial Purposes: The Mayor shall be
recognized as the head of the Municipal government for all ceremonial purposes.
   F.   Vice Mayor Serve In Absence Of Mayor: During the absence, disability or
suspension of the Mayor, the Vice Mayor shall assume the Mayor's duties. (2007
Code § 1-20)
1-7-6: ORDINANCES:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   The enacting clause of all ordinances passed by the City Commission
shall be: "BE IT ORDAINED by the City Commission of the City of Waurika,
Oklahoma", and of all ordinances proposed by the voters under their power of
initiative, "BE IT ORDAINED by the People of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma".
      2.   Every proposed ordinance shall be read and a vote of a majority of
all the Commission shall be required for its final passage.
      3.   The Mayor shall have no power to veto any ordinance.
      4.   Every ordinance, except those exempted by State law, shall be
published by title or in full, within fifteen (15) days after its passage, in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City or County, or posted in ten
(10) public places within the City.
      5.   Every ordinance, except an emergency ordinance, shall become
effective thirty (30) days after its final passage, unless it specifies a later
date.
      6.   An emergency ordinance is an ordinance which, in the judgment of the
City Commission, is necessary for the immediate preservation of the local
