approved by the city inspector may be used so long as the degree of protection
afforded by the substituted devices or structures is not less than the
protection afforded by the enclosure, gate and latch described herein. (Ord.
11082021-12. 11-8-2021)
CHAPTER 3
BUILDING RELATED OFFICIALS
SECTION:
10-3-1: Registration Of Certain Contractors
10-3-2: Municipal Building Inspector
10-3-3: Electrical Inspector
10-3-4: Plumbing Inspector
10-3-5: Mechanical Inspector
10-3-1: REGISTRATION OF CERTAIN CONTRACTORS:
   A.   Plumbing And Gas Fitting:
      1.   Any person desiring to engage in the business of plumbing or
plumbing contracting in the City shall first register with the Office of the
City Clerk. All registrants shall be State licensed.
      2.   No person shall do any plumbing, gas fitting, extensions, connection
of fixtures or repairs to any gas fitting, except a State licensed and locally
registered plumber, as provided in this Code.
      3.   The fee for plumber's registration shall be twenty dollars ($20.00)
per year.
   B.   Electricians:
      1.   All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations or individuals
engaged, or hereafter engaging, in the business of installing electrical
fixtures, wiring or apparatus in or on any building within the City shall
register with the Office of the City Clerk before they may engage in said
activities. All registrants shall be State licensed.
      2.   The electrician's registration fee shall be twenty dollars ($20.00)
per year.
   C.   Mechanical Contractors:
      1.   All persons in the business of designing, assembling, erecting,
constructing, installing, altering, servicing, repairing or maintaining
refrigeration, air conditioning, heating and/or ventilation systems must first
register with the Office of the City Clerk. All registrants must be State
licensed, if required.
      2.   The mechanical contractor's registration fee shall be twenty dollars
($20.00) per year.
   D.   Air Conditioning And Refrigeration Work: It shall be unlawful for any
person to install or make repairs on any air conditioning, refrigeration or
heating system without registering in accord with the provisions of this title.
It shall likewise be unlawful for any contractor to employ any person to do
such work unless such employee is registered under the provisions of this
section.
   E.   Right Of Entry For Building Inspector: Every person owning, leasing,
operating or in possession of any building or structure within the City shall
permit the Municipal building inspector to enter such building or structure as
often as it shall be deemed necessary by said inspector for the purpose of
discharging any duties prescribed by this title, and it shall be unlawful for
any owner, occupant or lessee of any premises to prevent or to refuse to permit
such entry. Said inspector shall, upon request of the owner, occupant or lessee
of any premises, exhibit the authority to make such entry.
   F.   Request For Variance: If, in the performance of any work under this
title, the contractor finds that, on account of the mechanical construction of
the building, location of fixtures, or some other reason, it would be
impossible to abide by the letter of this title, the Municipal building
inspector may be asked for a variance, by stating reasons for any changes and
setting forth the conditions, with a statement of the desire to request
exceptions to the provisions of this title for the particular job. If said
inspector finds that the conditions warrant and that it would be impractical
and unreasonable to require strict conformance, a special ruling may be made,
to safeguard life and property, on the proposed work. In all such cases,
persons engaged in such work or installation, and holding registration under
this title, shall be notified in writing of the decision.
   G.   Revocation Or Suspension Of Registration; Reasons: The Municipal
building inspector may revoke or suspend the registration of any person,
persons or corporation convicted of any violation of this title, or for any of
the following reasons:
      1.   Wilful fraud or misrepresentation practiced in procuring or renewing
any registration or license;
      2.   Dishonesty;
      3.   Gross incompetency;
      4.   Conduct likely to, or intended to, deceive or defraud the public;
      5.   The loaning of any license, registration or permit to any person or
persons for any reason whatsoever;
      6.   The obtaining of compensation by fraud or misrepresentation;
      7.   The wilful advertising or publishing, or otherwise making known, of
any grossly false, fraudulent or misleading statements of business skill,
knowledge or methods of operation;
      8.   The construction, design, installation, alteration, repair or
maintenance of any refrigeration or air conditioning equipment in such a manner
as to be detrimental to the safety, health or welfare of the general public;
      9.   For any misconduct in the use of a registration or transaction
thereunder; or
      10.   For the violation or disregard of any regulations of the City.
(2007 Code § 4-103)
10-3-2: MUNICIPAL BUILDING INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: There is hereby created the office of Municipal building
inspector within the administrative structure of the City. The Municipal
building inspector shall be appointed by the City Manager; said appointment
shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service. This position may
also be filled, on a contractual basis, if necessary.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The powers and duties of the Municipal building
inspector shall be as follows:
      1.   To enforce all provisions of the codes adopted by this Code;
      2.   To receive and process applications required by such adopted codes
or this Code;
      3.   To review building permit applications, other permit applications,
issue required certificates and serve as the Zoning Administration Officer for
the City;
      4.   To examine premises for which permits have been issued under such
adopted codes or this Code and make necessary inspections to see that the
provisions of the adopted codes or this Code are complied with and that
construction is done safely;
      5.   To investigate, when requested by the City Commission, or when the
public interest so requires, matters referred to in such adopted codes and
render written reports on the same;
      6.   To issue such notices or orders as may be necessary to enforce
compliance with the adopted codes or this Code, to remove illegal or unsafe
conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during construction or to
require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures; and
      7.   To make inspections required under the provisions of the codes
adopted by this Code, or to ensure that inspections are made by a duly
appointed assistant.
   C.   Acting Building Inspector: During any temporary absence of the
Municipal building inspector, the City Manager may designate an acting building
inspector; the City Clerk shall serve as acting building inspector, unless the
City Manager designates another person as such, by motion.
   D.   Right Of Entry For Inspections: The Municipal building inspector, while
in the discharge of official duty, shall have the authority to enter any
building or premises for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the
construction or equipment contained therein, or its installation.
   E.   Act As Other Inspectors: The Municipal building inspector may perform
electrical or plumbing inspections and may also serve as the electrical or
plumbing inspector, if so designated by the City Manager.
   F.   Request For Inspection By State: In the event the City is absent an
inspector or a construction project is such that the City inspector does not
believe he is qualified to perform the inspections, the City Manager may
request an inspection from the State Health Department. (2007 Code § 1-28)
10-3-3: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: There is hereby created the office of electrical inspector
within the administrative structure of the City. The electrical inspector shall
be appointed by the City Manager.
   B.   Qualifications: The electrical inspector shall have had experience as
an electrician, shall be of good moral character, shall be knowledgeable of the
approved methods of electrical construction and shall be certified by the
State.
   C.   Powers And Duties: The electrical inspector shall have all of the
powers and duties prescribed by the National Electrical Code adopted by this
Code, shall be certified by the State, and shall also ensure that all Municipal
ordinances and regulations relating to electrical wiring and maintenance are
properly enforced.
   D.   Request For Inspection By State: In the event the City is absent an
inspector or a construction project is such that the City inspector does not
believe he is qualified to perform the inspection, the City Manager may request
an inspection from the State Health Department. (2007 Code § 1-29)
10-3-4: PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: There is hereby created the office of plumbing inspector
within the administrative structure of the City. The plumbing inspector shall
be appointed by the City Manager; the plumbing inspector may also hold other
positions in the Municipal government.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The plumbing inspector shall have all of the powers
and duties prescribed by the Plumbing Code adopted by this Code, shall be
certified by the State, and shall also ensure that all Municipal ordinances and
regulations relating to water and sanitary plumbing are properly enforced.
   C.   Request For Inspection By State: In the event the City is absent an
inspector or a construction project is such that the City inspector does not
believe he is qualified to perform the inspection, the City Manager may request
an inspection from the State Health Department. (2007 Code § 1-30)
10-3-5: MECHANICAL INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: There is hereby created the position of mechanical
inspector for the City, said person to be appointed by the City Manager.
   B.   Qualifications: The mechanical inspector shall have experience with,
and knowledge of, the operations covered by the City's adopted Mechanical Code.
   C.   Request For Inspection By State: In the event the City is absent an
inspector or a construction project is such that the City inspector does not
believe he is qualified to perform the inspection, the City Manager may request
an inspection from the State Health Department. (2007 Code § 1-31)
CHAPTER 4
PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES
SECTION:
10-4-1: General Building Permit Requirements
10-4-2: Fence Building Permits
10-4-3: Mobile, Manufactured Or Modular Home Placement Permits
10-4-4: Building Permit Requirements In Flood Hazard Areas
10-4-5: House Moving Permits
10-4-6: Pavement Cutting Permits
10-4-7: Ditching Permits
10-4-8: Permits For Pipes Across Streets
10-4-9: Demolition Permits
10-4-10: Liquefied Petroleum Gas State Permits
10-4-11: Certificate Of Appropriateness For Restoration Work
10-4-12: Building Inspection Fee Schedule
10-4-1: GENERAL BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required For Various Construction Activities: No person shall
erect, enlarge, construct, relocate, substantially improve, repair, place,
alter, move or demolish any building, structure, mobile, modular or
manufactured home, or initiate any other construction, without first obtaining
a separate building permit for each such building or structure from the Office
of the City Clerk. Said permit shall be in addition to, and separate from, all
other requirements for zoning clearance permits, occupancy certificates or
certificates of appropriateness.
   B.   Building Permit Regulations And Application Process:
      1.   Administration Of Building Permit Process: The Office of the City
Clerk shall be responsible for the administration of the building permit
process; provided, that building permit application forms may be obtained from,
and submitted to, the City building inspector.
      2.   Permit Application Information And Accompanying Documents:
Applications for building permits shall contain all applicable information
required on the building permit form, and shall be accompanied by drawings of
the proposed work (drawn to scale), showing floor plans, structural details,
computations and such additional information as may be required of the
applicant by the Office of the City Clerk, the City building inspector, this
Code or the City Commission.
      3.   Application For Permit; Fee: All applications for building permits
shall be signed and in writing, upon an official blank form supplied by the
Office of the City Clerk or the City building inspector, and shall be submitted
to either of said officials, along with the required fee.
      4.   Building Permit Fee Determination: Building permit fees shall be as
determined by the City Commission, and shall be based primarily upon the City
costs incurred in the administration of the City building permit system.
      5.   Extensive Review Of Application: Upon receipt of a complete building
permit application and the required fee, the City Clerk shall immediately turn
the application over to the City building inspector, who shall review the
application to ensure that:
         a.   The involved land is properly zoned for the proposed use;
         b.   Applicable zoning district provisions (including Floodway and
Floodway Fringe District provisions), and any applicable historic preservation
provisions, have been met;
         c.   Legally-dedicated roadway access is available, and proof of such
dedication has been provided;
         d.   Adequate and sanitary provisions have been made for utilities,
and fire protection is also adequate;
         e.   All easements and street right-of-way areas provided in the
recorded plat, if any, are not encroached upon; to this end, the builder of any
structure located in the City shall, by receipt of the building permit, agree
to furnish the purchaser(s) of the structure(s) with a survey of the lot(s) and
structure(s) thereon, upon completion of construction, indicating compliance
with this requirement; said survey shall be signed by a surveyor licensed in
the State of Oklahoma;
         f.   All other floodplain regulations, if applicable, have been met
and the required information provided;
         g.   Applicable historic preservation regulations have been met
(chapter 5 of this title and any appropriate provisions of chapter 9 of this
title); and
         h.   All other required City permits and/or licenses have been
obtained.
      6.   Issuance Authorized And Forwarded To City Clerk And Applicant: If
the City building inspector is satisfied that the proposed work described in
the application and attached materials conform to the requirements of the
adopted Zoning Ordinance, Building Code and other regulations and requirements,
the issuance of the building permit shall be authorized by signing the
application and forwarding it to the Office of the City Clerk, who shall return
a copy to the applicant.
      7.   Disapproval; Reasons Listed; Resubmitting Application: If the
application or attached materials do not conform to pertinent City regulations,
the City building inspector shall not approve said application, but shall
return the application to the City Clerk, along with written reason(s) for
disapproval. The City Clerk shall return the application, with written reason
(s) attached, to the applicant. The applicant may subsequently amend the
application, if possible, and resubmit it, or initiate other action to correct
the deficiencies.
      8.   Completion Of Review Process In Timely Manner: The City building
inspector and the Office of the City Clerk shall complete all required review
processes in an efficient and effective manner, without unreasonable or
unnecessary delay.
      9.   Restrictions Allowed On Approved Permit: A building permit, once
approved and issued, shall be construed as authorization to proceed with the
work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set
aside any City regulations, nor shall such issuance prevent the City building
inspector from thereafter requiring a correction of errors in plans,
construction or a violation of this Code.
      10.   Time Limit For Initiation Of Work: If the work allowed under an
issued building permit has not been initiated within six (6) months from the
issuance date of said permit, such permit shall become null and void, unless a
request for an extension is submitted to, and approved by, the City Commission;
such extension request must be submitted to the City Commission prior to the
end of said six (6) month period. If said permit becomes null and void, a new
permit must be obtained and the regular fee incident thereto collected, in
order for the work to be initiated or resumed.
      11.   Record Of Permits Issued And Fee Payments: The City Clerk shall
keep a permanent and accurate accounting of all building permits, and shall
transmit copies of each permit issued to the City building inspector, for
information purposes. The City Clerk shall keep a permanent and accurate record
of all building permit fee payments.
      12.   Revocation Of Building Permit: The City Clerk may revoke a building
permit in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a
material fact in the application or attached materials on which the building
permit approval was based. Noncompliance shall also be grounds for non-issuance
or revocation of a permit by the City Clerk.
      13.   Display Of Permit On Project Or Site: Building permits shall be
conspicuously displayed on the project or site, in a manner visible from the
street.
      14.   Monitoring Of Utility Hookups: The City Clerk and the City building
inspector shall monitor City utility hookup requests and shall not allow City
utilities to be turned on to any unit, structure or project for which a
building permit has not been issued.
      15.   Appeals From Aggrieved Persons: Appeals from any person concerning
a decision of the City Clerk relative to the granting of building permits,
shall be taken to the Administrative Body, who shall act as the Permit Board of
Appeals for the City. The Board of City Commissioners hereby designates the
City Manager, Chief of the Fire Department, and the Chief of the Police
Department as the Administrative Body. At least two (2) members of the
Administrative Body shall appear for hearings and a finding requires a majority
vote of the Administrative Body. The aggrieved person shall have the right of
appeal to the Board of City Commissioners from any order of the Administrative
Body. Such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the
City Clerk within ten (10) days after the administrative order is rendered.
      16.   Conflicts; Prevailing Provisions: In the event of any conflict
between the building permit provisions delineated herein and any provision(s)
of the Building Code adopted by the City Commission, the provisions of this
chapter shall prevail.
   C.   Minor Repairs Not Requiring Permit: Minor repairs of buildings or
structures, the cost of which shall not exceed one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00), may be made without obtaining a building permit; provided,
that all plumbing, electrical or mechanical work covered by adopted model
construction codes, shall require an appropriate permit. Construction of
accessory buildings under one hundred fifty (150) square feet in area may also
occur without a building permit; provided, that the structure cannot have any
water, sewer or electrical hookups, and the structure is not to be constructed
within any dedicated road or alley right-of-way, or in violation of the Zoning
Ordinance. (2019 Code; amd. Ord. 06082020-12, 6-8-2020)
10-4-2: FENCE BUILDING PERMITS:
An applicant for a building permit related to the construction, replacement or
major repair (more than fifty percent (50%) of any type of fence in the City
shall comply with the following requirements:
   A.   The fence shall be in full compliance with the city's adopted Zoning
Ordinance, including specific references, if any, to setback limitations;
   B.   Any fencing located in front of the main structure shall be no higher
than four feet (4');
   C.   Fencing shall not cause any obstruction to any public right-of-way or
drainage easement, excluding utility easements (where fencing shall be placed
on either the easement line of the property line, depending on the remaining
fence placements in the adjacent lots);
   D.   No fencing shall be allowed to obstruct the sight triangle
intersections or comers.
   E.   See Attachment "A" below.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/87d9ba68b3e5352bd73eccdf8685cf79810481c7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1445.png]
(2019 Code; amd. Ord. 09142020-14, 9-14-2020; Ord. 02142022-03, 2-14-2022)
10-4-3: MOBILE, MANUFACTURED OR MODULAR HOME PLACEMENT PERMITS:
No mobile, manufactured or modular home shall be placed on improved or
unimproved real estate without first obtaining a separate building permit for
each such home from the Office of the City Clerk. (2019 Code)
10-4-4: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS IN FLOOD HAZARD AREAS:
In addition to the building permit requirements in section
10-4-1 of this chapter, the following shall be required to obtain a building
permit in a flood hazard area:
   A.   Manmade Changes To Real Estate: No manmade change to improved or
unimproved real estate located within a designated flood hazard area,
including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging,
filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations, shall be initiated
until a separate building permit has been obtained for each such operation from
the Office of the City Clerk.
   B.   Permit Applications And Requirements For Development: Building permit
applications for development, location, demolition or alteration within
delineated flood hazard areas (as shown on the community's official Flood
Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), dated January 6, 1983, including a Letter of Map
Revision (LOMR), effective November 2001, which are hereby adopted by reference
as if set out fully herein), shall be reviewed by the City building inspector
to ensure that all of the following requirements are met:
      1.   All building sites shall be reasonably safe from flooding; if a
proposed building site is in a flood-prone area, all new construction and
substantial improvement (including the placement of pre-fabricated buildings
and mobile homes) shall:
         a.   Be designed, modified and/or adequately anchored to prevent
flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; all manufactured
housing to be placed within Zone A on the community's Flood Hazard Boundary Map
(FHBM) shall be anchored by providing over-the-top and frame ties to ground
anchors; over-the-top ties shall be provided at each of the four (4) corners of
the mobile home, with two (2) additional ties per side at intermediate points,
and manufactured homes less than fifty feet (50') long requiring one additional
tie per side; frame ties shall be provided at each corner of the home, with
five (5) additional ties per side at intermediate points, and manufactured
homes less than fifty feet (50') long requiring four (4) additional ties per
side; all components of the anchoring system shall be capable of carrying a
force of four thousand eight hundred (4,800) pounds; any additions to the home
shall be similarly anchored;
         b.   Be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to
flood damage;
         c.   Be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood
damage; and
         d.   Be constructed with electrical, heating, plumbing, ventilation
and air conditioning equipment and other service facilities that are designed
and/or located to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the
components during conditions of flooding.
      2.   All new and replacement water supply systems within flood- prone
areas shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters
into the systems.
      3.   All new and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to
minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and
discharges from the systems into floodwaters.
      4.   On-site waste disposal systems within flood-prone areas shall be
located to avoid impairment to them, or contamination from them, during
flooding.
      5.   The City building inspector shall utilize all available 100-year
flood elevation data to review building permit applications, and shall require
that all applications for development within a flood-prone area be accompanied
by: a) the elevation of the lowest habitable floor (including basement) of all
new or substantially improved structures; and b) a certificate signed by a
registered professional engineer or architect, stating that the floodproofing
methods to be utilized are adequate to withstand the flood depths, pressures,
velocities, impact and uplift forces, and other factors associated with the
100-year flood, and indicating the specific elevation to which the structure
will be floodproofed. New construction and substantial improvements, with fully
enclosed areas below the lowest floor that are subject to flooding, shall be
designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls
by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. Designs for meeting this
requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or
architect, or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria:
         a.   A minimum of two (2) openings having a total net area of not less
than one square inch for every one square foot of enclosed area subject to
flooding shall be provided;
         b.   The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one foot (1')
above grade; and
         c.   Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other
coverings or devices; provided, that they permit the automatic entry and exit
of floodwaters.
      6.   All new construction or substantial improvement of residential
structures within Zones A1-30 on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM)
shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated one foot (1') above
the level of the 100-year flood.
      7.   Within Zones A1-30 on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM),
all manufactured housing not in a park or subdivision, all new manufactured
housing parks and subdivisions, all expansions to existing manufactured housing
parks and subdivisions, and all repairs, reconstruction or improvement of
streets, utilities and/or pads in existing manufactured housing parks or
subdivisions, shall be located, developed, expanded or improved according to
the following criteria:
         a.   All manufactured housing shall be placed, or be capable of being
placed, on compacted fill or on pilings, so that the lowest floor of the home
will be one foot (1') above the level of the 100-year flood;
         b.   All lots shall have adequate provisions for surface drainage and
access; and
         c.   All manufactured housing to be elevated on pilings shall: 1) be
placed on lots large enough to permit steps; 2) provide for piling foundations
to be placed in stable or stabilized soils, no more than ten feet (10') apart;
and 3) provide for reinforcement of piers more than six feet (6') above ground
level.
      8.   All new construction or substantial improvement of residential
structures located within any AO (Area of Shallow Flooding) Zone, as shown on
the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), shall have the lowest floor,
including basement, elevated above the highest adjacent grade or the crown of
the nearest street, one foot (1') above the depth number specified for the area
on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM). Within Zone AH or AO, adequate
drainage paths around structures on slopes shall be required.
      9.   All new construction or substantial improvement of nonresidential
structures within Zones A1-30 on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM)
shall:
         a.   Have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated one foot (1')
above the level of the 100-year flood; or
         b.   Be designed, together with attendant utility and sanitary
facilities, so that, below the level of the 100-year flood, the structure is
watertight, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and
contains structural components capable of resisting hydrostatic and
hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy.
      10.   All new construction or substantial improvement of nonresidential
structures within any AO (Area of Shallow Flooding) Zone on the City's Flood
Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) shall:
         a.   Have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated above the
highest adjacent grade or the crown of the nearest street, one foot (1') above
the depth number specified on the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM); or
         b.   Be completely floodproofed, along with attendant utility and
sanitary facilities, to one foot (1') above the depth number specified on the
City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), so that any space below the level is
watertight, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and
contains structural components capable of resisting hydrostatic and
hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy; and
         c.   Be required to include, within Zones AH or AO, adequate drainage
paths around structures on slopes, to guide floodwaters around and away from
proposed structures.
      11.   The requirements of this section shall also be in effect for
building permit applications for development located within any A99 Zones on
the City's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM).
      12.   Floodways, as designated on the City's Official Flood Hazard
Boundary Map (FHBM), are hazardous areas due to: a) the velocity of floodwaters
which carry debris and potentially damaging projectiles; and b) the creation of
severe erosion problems; the following provisions apply within designated
floodway areas:
         a.   Encroachments are prohibited, including fill, new construction,
substantial improvements and other developments, unless certification by a
professional registered engineer or architect is provided, demonstrating that
encroachments shall not result in any increase in flood levels during
occurrence of the base flood discharge.
         b.   If the provisions of subsection B1 of this section are satisfied,
all new construction and substantial improvements shall comply with all
applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of this Code.
   C.   Additional Inspector Responsibilities Concerning Development In Flood
Hazard Areas: The City building inspector shall have the following additional
responsibilities in the review of building permit applications for development,
location, demolition or alteration within a delineated flood hazard area:
      1.   Building permit applications shall be reviewed to ensure that all
necessary governmental agency permits required by State or Federal law have
been obtained.
      2.   In the case of building permit applications for alteration or
relocation of a watercourse, the City building inspector shall:
         a.   Notify adjacent communities and the State Flood Insurance
Coordinating Office prior to such work (and submit copies of such notification
to the Federal Flood Insurance Administrator); and
         b.   Obtain written assurances from the building permit applicant that
the flood-carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of the
watercourse will be maintained.
      3.   For the purpose of determining future flood insurance risk premium
rates, the City building inspector shall maintain records of:
         a.   The elevation of the lowest habitable floor of all new or
substantially improved structures; and
         b.   Floodproofing certificates (including the specific elevation to
which the structures are floodproofed).
      4.   When a regulatory floodway has not been designated, the City
building inspector must require that no new construction, substantial
improvements, or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within
Zones A1-30 and AE on the community's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the
cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other
existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface
elevation of the base flood more than one foot (1') at any point within the
community.
      5.   The City building inspector shall utilize the full range of the
community's Floodplain Management Regulations in this review.
   D.   Building Permit Issuance; Nonliability: Issuance of a building permit
for development within an identified flood hazard area shall not create
liability on the part of any City official for any flood damage resulting from
reliance upon the provisions of this section, or any administrative decision
lawfully made thereunder. (2019 Code)
10-4-5: HOUSE MOVING PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: Before any person shall move any house, building or
heavy structure (but not including a mobile or manufactured home) on or over
any nonfederal or nonstate roadway within or through the City, it shall first
be necessary to obtain a house moving permit to do so from the Office of the
City Clerk.
   B.   Permit Fee: The fee for a permit to move such house or structure shall
be twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event it is necessary to move utility lines,
poles, signs or other structures to facilitate the move, the cost therefor will
be paid by the applicant, in addition to the normal fee.
   C.   Bond Or Cash Deposit: No permit shall be issued to any person to move a
house or structure unless the person has in effect a bond or a cash deposit
with the City Clerk in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned
that the mover will indemnify the owners of any property (public or private,
including pavement, curbs, etc.) for any damage thereto resulting from the
moving of any house or structure, and holding the City harmless from liability
for any such damage.
   D.   Determination Of Route; Rules For Moving: It shall be the duty of the
building inspector to approve or determine the route that may be used and the
potential for damage, if any, to any property; such rules and regulations as
are necessary to promote an effective move and the protection of persons and
property may also be prescribed by the City Manager. The mover shall erect all
necessary danger signals during the operation of moving.
   E.   House Mover Responsible For Damage: Any person moving any house or any
other structure on or over any street or alley, shall be liable (personally and
upon bond) for any damage to trees, public property, persons or any matter
whatsoever resulting from such moving. This shall not be construed to authorize
any person to cut or trim any trees, or commit any injury to any public or
private property which cannot be immediately restored to its former condition;
no permit shall authorize any moving under any conditions which will promote
such damage. (2007 Code § 4-21)
10-4-6: PAVEMENT CUTTING PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: Any public utility contractor, firm or other person
desiring to bore or cut into, or in any manner cross, any public street, alley,
sidewalk or public ground of any sort, whether paved, graveled, bricked,
blacktopped or not for any purpose whatever, shall first obtain a pavement
cutting permit from the City Clerk to cross or open such street, alley,
sidewalk or ground. (Exception to this requirement will be made only when a
bona fide emergency exists. In such case, the Municipal building inspector, the
City Clerk or the City Manager shall be notified at the earliest practical
time.)
   B.   Permit Fees: The fees for such permits shall be:
      1.   Excavation in concrete pavement or surface: Thirty dollars ($30.00)
(minimum) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) per square yard.
      2.   Excavation in brick, asphalt or oil mat pavement or surface: Twenty
dollars ($20.00) (minimum) plus ten dollars ($10.00) per square yard.
      3.   Excavation in untreated or unimproved street or surface: Five
dollars ($5.00) (minimum) plus one dollar ($1.00) per square yard.
      4.   Modification or removal of curb or curbing: Ten dollars ($10.00).
   C.   Construction Requirements: On all-weather streets or alleys with
bituminous or concrete surface, boring will be required without exception;
cutting or ditching will be allowed on all streets or alleys with dirt or
gravel surface. If for any reason these requirements cannot be complied with,
cutting of a street will be allowed, but shall require the street surface to be
replaced with a minimum of six inches (6") of concrete, twenty four inches
(24") wider than the cut or the ditch.
   D.   Restoration Of Surface: When any street, alley, sidewalk or public
ground has been crossed for the purposes of laying gas, water or sewage pipe,
or for any other purpose, the surface will be restored with similar material
and workmanship to that existing in the street, alley, sidewalk or public
ground before the same was torn up; all work shall be completed and refilled to
the satisfaction of the Municipal building inspector, or a representative, and
approval issued as previously stated.
   E.   Materials For Backfill: Materials used to backfill any opening in a
street or alley shall be placed in lifts not to exceed ten inches (10"), and
each lift shall be tamped either mechanically or by hand to ninety five percent
(95%) compaction. Six inches (6") of crushed aggregate base material shall be
used to fill to the existing surface on all streets and alleys. Openings in
concrete surfaces shall be filled with base material to within four inches (4")
of the bottom of the slab. The remaining four inches (4") of the opening shall
be filled with sand to the bottom of the concrete slab to be replaced. On major
streets, the thickness of crushed aggregate base material required may vary.
   F.   Lights And Barricades Required: In all cases where the surface of the
street, alley, sidewalk or public ground is disturbed, the party so cutting
into the opening shall place lights at night and maintain suitable barricades
at all times to protect persons from danger.
   G.   Failure To Comply; Penalty: Should any person, firm, corporation,
contractor or franchise holder with the City fail to comply, said party shall
be summoned before the City Commission for removal of their license or
franchise. Any person not licensed with the City who fails to comply, shall be
fined and required to pay costs of repair plus labor. (2007 Code § 4-22)
10-4-7: DITCHING PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to initiate any ditching operation involving any public easement,
right-of-way, place, area or building within the City without first obtaining a
ditching permit from the Office of the City Clerk; said permit shall first be
approved by the City Manager.
   B.   Permit Fee: The fee for such permit shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00).
   C.   Conditions For Permit Issuance: Such permit shall be issued only if the
applicant meets the following conditions:
      1.   The applicant shall provide a map of the proposed project to the
Mayor prior to initiating work; said map shall show, or have placed upon it,
all Municipal utility line locations in the project area, and all areas of
public easement, rights-of- way or places, areas or buildings potentially
affected by the proposed project.
      2.   The applicant shall provide written proof that there is full
coordination with all other applicable utility companies (telephone, electric,
gas and CATV) and complete awareness of the locations of all such lines.
      3.   The applicant shall provide a surety bond (or cash deposit),
suitable to the City as to dollar amount and form, to ensure that any damage
will be repaired; upon completion of the project, the City will review any
damage claims and make appropriate arrangements.
      4.   The applicant shall agree, in writing, to maintain proper
safeguards, particularly at night.
   D.   Violations: Violation of any of these provisions shall be grounds for
revocation of the permit at any time. (2007 Code § 4-23)
10-4-8: PERMITS FOR PIPES ACROSS STREETS:
   A.   Permit Required: Oil and gas companies, and other persons, firms and
corporations not operating pursuant to a franchise granted by the Municipality
or not operating pursuant to a license or permit granted by the State
Corporation Commission, shall secure a permit from the Office of the City Clerk
before placing, installing, laying, constructing, operating or maintaining any
pipe, cable, wire, conduit or line across, over, under, along, through or upon
any street, alley, public way or public place within the corporate limits of
the City; said permit shall first be approved by the City Manager.
   B.   Contents Of Application: The application for the permit shall specify:
      1.   The location of the pipe, cable, wire conduit or line; and
      2.   The privileges and proposed terms which the applicant desires to
secure from the City and to exercise.
   C.   Permit Revocation; Reasons: If the permit is granted, the City Manager
will grant it on written terms which are mutually agreeable. The City Manager
may revoke said permit after adequate opportunity for a public hearing, for any
of the following reasons:
      1.   Failure to abide by the terms on which the permit was granted;
      2.   Violation of State law or Municipal ordinances; or
      3.   Failure to provide for the protection of the public peace, health,
safety or welfare.
   D.   Payment Of Fees: The applicant shall pay such fees for such permit and
for its periodic renewal, as the City Commission may establish by motion.
   E.   Authority To Refuse Renewal Of Permit: The City Manager may refuse to
renew a permit.
   F.   Bond Required: The City Commission may require an applicant to provide
a bond for the protection of the City and/or the public in such sum and with
such terms as said City Commission deems desirable. When the City Commission
requires such a bond, a permit shall have no force or effect unless the
required bond is also in effect. (2007 Code § 4-24)
10-4-9: DEMOLITION PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: A demolition permit shall be required, in addition to
the regular building permit, prior to the demolition of any building or part
thereof.
   B.   Permit Fees: The fees for a permit to wreck a building within the fire
limits shall be six dollars ($6.00) for a one story building and four dollars
($4.00) for each additional story. If outside the fire limits, the fees shall
be four dollars ($4.00) and two dollars ($2.00), respectively.
   C.   Application Information: Application for permits to wreck or demolish
any building or part thereof shall be accompanied by a statement in writing by
the owner or agent, giving the full name and residence of each of the owners of
the building to be demolished, the name and address of the person who is to do
the work and any other information which may be required.
   D.   Taking Down Walls And Materials:
      1.   In no case shall any wall be taken down more than one story in
advance of any other wall.
      2.   All material and debris shall be immediately lowered to the ground
and shall not be placed on the floors of the building. (2007 Code § 4-25)
10-4-10: LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS STATE PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to manufacture,
fabricate, assemble, install or repair any system, container, apparatus or
appliance to be used for the transportation, storage, dispensation or
utilization of liquefied petroleum gas, or to transport, handle or store such
gas, unless such person has complied and complies with, all provisions of the
State law and local ordinances relating thereto, and has any permit which may
be required by State law. No storage of liquefied petroleum gas, except by
retail customers, in reasonable amounts, strictly intended for their own use,
shall be permitted within the corporate limits of the City. (2007 Code § 4-26)
10-4-11: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS FOR RESTORATION WORK:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of issuing a Certificate of Appropriateness are to
make all concerned parties aware that all required submittals and approvals
have been completed and that the proper permit may be issued for the start of
restoration work.
   B.   Certificate Required: The Certificate of Appropriateness is required
before a building permit is issued for any of the following to occur in a
Historic District or on a locally designated historic landmark or historic
site:
      1.   Demolition of property;
      2.   Moving of property;
      3.   Material change(s) such as exterior reconstruction, alteration or
color changes other than those approved in the original application; or
      4.   Building of new structures on property.
   C.   Application Requirements; Fee: The following procedures shall be used
for applications:
      1.   A ten dollar ($10.00) filing fee shall be collected by the Office of
the City Clerk.
      2.   The applicant shall submit for review any sketches, plans, drawings,
photos or other information which would clearly show the Preservation
Commission what changes will be made.
      3.   The application shall be filed with the City Clerk.
      4.   The Certificate of Appropriateness shall be reviewed by the
Preservation Commission in generally the same manner as a rezoning application
and request.
      5.   If work authorized by a Certificate of Appropriateness is not begun
within sixty (60) days, the Certificate of Appropriateness shall expire and
reapplication must be made, unless a 30-day extension is granted by the
Preservation Commission; no more than two (2) extensions may be permitted on
one project. (2007 Code § 4-27)
10-4-12: BUILDING INSPECTION FEE SCHEDULE:
   A.   All building review, management, and inspection services within the
City limits of the City of Waurika will be subject to review and inspection
fees (Building Inspection Fee Schedule), including residential building plan
review and inspections, commercial construction plan review and inspections,
alteration plan review and inspections, new construction and additions plan
review and inspections, accessibility plan review and inspections, fire code
review and inspections, planning and zoning services, management, and
inspections, and fast track plan review services.
   B.   City personnel, subject to direction as the Board of City Commissioners
may give by motion or resolution, may establish, reduce or increase the
building inspection fee schedule. (Ord. 03092020-02, 3-9-2020)
CHAPTER 5
HISTORIC PRESERVATION
SECTION:
10-5-1: Statement Of Purpose
10-5-2: Definitions
10-5-3: Criteria For Historic Designation
10-5-4: Procedures For Historic Designation
10-5-5: Criteria For Evaluation Of Proposed Designations
10-5-6: Voluntary Restrictive Covenants
10-5-7: General Design Review Policies
10-5-8: Specific Design Review Criteria
10-5-9: Design Review Process; Certificates And Clearances
10-5-1: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
   A.   This chapter is designed to allow for the designation, and subsequent
protection of, properties which have been determined to be architecturally,
archaeologically, culturally or historically significant to the City, and to
allow interested parties the opportunity to arrange for the preservation of
such properties.
   B.   The purposes of this chapter are to:
      1.   Strengthen the City's economic base through stimulation of
structural and district conservation, reuse and revitalization;
      2.   Stabilize and preserve property values;
      3.   Promote harmonious, orderly and efficient growth and development of
the community, through the integration of the preservation and comprehensive
planning processes within the City;
      4.   Safeguard the cultural and architectural heritage of the City;
      5.   Promote the designation of historic properties and landmarks and the
creation of Historic Districts for the educational, cultural, economic and
general welfare of the public; and
      6.   Enhance the environmental quality of neighborhoods. (2007 Code § 4-
80)
10-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS: The approval issued by the City's Preservation
Commission for: a) alterations of historic properties designated under this
chapter or the City's Zoning Ordinance; b) demolition of such properties; c)
new construction in a district designated under said ordinances as historic; or
d) projects that may impact upon a designated historic property or Historic
District 1 .
CHIEF ELECTED LOCAL OFFICIAL: The Mayor of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma.
CITY COMMISSION: The Governing Body of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma; said body
may also be known as, or called, the "City Commission" or the "City Council".
HISTORIC DISTRICT: A geographically definable area with a concentration or
linkage of significant sites, buildings, structures or monuments that are
unified historically, architecturally, archaeologically or culturally.
HISTORIC PROPERTY: An individual structure, building, site or monument which
contributes to the historical, architectural, archeological and/or cultural
heritage of the City of Waurika, Oklahoma.
LOCAL LEGISLATION: This Code, statutes, ordinances, etc., which create the
Preservation Commission and comprehensively set forth its functions,
responsibilities, membership and other implementation provisions.
NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES: The national list of districts, sites,
buildings, structures and objects significant in American history,
architecture, archeology, engineering and culture, maintained by the Secretary
of the Interior under authority of the National Preservation Act, as amended.
ORDINARY MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR: Any work not requiring a building permit or
Certificate of Appropriateness, where the purpose is to stabilize and not
noticeably alter the property's exterior appearance. Any work not satisfying
the above requirements shall not be considered ordinary maintenance and repair
(i.e., painting previously unpainted brick).
PRESERVATION: Shall have any or all of the following meanings:
Adaptive Use: Restrained alteration to accommodate uses for which the property
was not originally constructed, but in such a way as to maintain the general
significant characteristics.
Conservation: Sustained use and appearance essentially in the property's
existing state.
Protection: Security of a property as it exists primarily through the
establishment of the mechanisms of this title.
Reconstruction: Process of recreation or reproduction by new construction, all
or parts of the form and detail of a vanished resource, as it appeared at a
specific period in time.
Rehabilitation: Process of returning a property to a state of efficiency or
soundness by repair or alteration, designed to encourage its continued use, but
without noticeably changing its exterior.
Restoration: Process of accurately recovering all or part of the form and
detail of a property and its setting as it appeared at a particular period of
time, by means of removal of later work and replacement of earlier work.
Stabilization: Process of applying measures designed to halt deterioration and
to establish the structural soundness of an unsafe or deteriorated property,
while maintaining the essential form as it presently exists, without noticeably
changing the exterior appearance.
PRESERVATION COMMISSION: The Waurika, Oklahoma, Preservation Commission, with
the powers and duties established in this chapter and in this Code.
SIGNIFICANT CHARACTERISTICS: Any or all of the following:
   A.   Cultural:
      1. Has noteworthy character, interest or value as part of the development
of the community, State or Nation; or
      2. Is associated with a noteworthy personality or past development; or
      3. Is the site of a noteworthy social, economic or political event.
   B.   Architectural:
      1. Exemplifies a distinctive artistic style or engineering specimen; or
      2. Represents the work of a particular designer, architect or contractor
whose work has influenced the community or Nation; or
      3. Contains elements of design, materials, detail, style or craftsmanship
unique to the past; or
      4. Is a distinctive part of, or related to a part of, a distinctive area
that should be preserved; or
      5. Represents a visual and established feature of a neighborhood, the
community or the skyline due to its location or physical features.
   C.   Archeological:
      1. Has yielded information, or is likely to yield information (based on
physical evidence), important to history or prehistory; or
      2. Is part of, or is related to, a distinctive geographical area which
should be developed or preserved according to a plan based on a cultural,
historical or architectural context.
   D.   Historical: Represents events of the past, important to the development
of the area, community, State or Nation.
STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER (SHPO): The official within the State of
Oklahoma who has been delegated and appointed by the Governor to administer the
Historic Preservation Program in the State. (2007 Code § 4-81)

1 1. See section
  10-4-11 of this title.
10-5-3: CRITERIA FOR HISTORIC DESIGNATION:
Historic landmark, historic site or Historic District status may be considered
for any natural or improved site or any area of particular historic,
architectural or cultural significance which:
   A.   Exemplifies or reflects the broad cultural, political, economic and
social history of the Nation, State or the City; or
   B.   Is identified with historic persons or with important events in
National, State or local history; or
   C.   Embodies the distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type
inherently valuable for the study of a period, style or method of construction
or of indigenous materials or craftsmanship; or
   D.   Is respective of the notable work of a landscape architect, contractor,
master builder, City planner, designer or architect whose work influenced a
particular age or period of development in the Nation, State, region or local
area. (2007 Code § 4-83)
10-5-4: PROCEDURES FOR HISTORIC DESIGNATION:
   A.   The Preservation Commission shall contact all owner(s) of real property
(excluding mineral rights) within the area of a proposed Historic District or
within three hundred feet (300') of any affected historic landmark or site, in
order to inform them of the subject area, time, date and place of the public
hearing(s) at which historic designation will be discussed; said notice shall
be mailed not less than twenty (20) days prior to the hearing of the
Preservation Commission, and shall also contain notices of the time, date and
place of the subsequent City Commission meeting at which final action is
proposed to be taken.
   B.   A legal notice, indicating the nature of the hearing, the area
involved, and the time, date and place of the hearing, shall be published once
in a newspaper of general circulation, at least fifteen (15) days prior to the
Preservation Commission's public hearing; said notice shall also contain the
time, date and place of the subsequent City Commission meeting at which final
action is proposed to take place.
   C.   Upon mailing of notification to the property owners within a proposed
Historic District or involving a historic structure or historic landmark, no
building permits will be issued nor will any use changes be granted until after
the City Commission approves or rejects the designation proposal for the
affected area or site.
   D.   A quorum of the Preservation Commission shall conduct the hearing. All
interested parties shall be given a reasonable opportunity to express their
opinions regarding the proposed designation(s). Said commission may establish
reasonable limits on the length of individual presentations. A record of the
hearing shall be made. The Preservation Commission's records may include the
name and address of each speaker, the organization or person represented (if
any), whether or not such person is an owner or holder of some interest in the
affected property or represents such owner or holder, and a summary of the
relevant portions of each statement.
   E.   Within fifteen (15) days after the hearing, the Preservation Commission
shall act upon the proposed designation. Said commission may approve, reject or
modify any proposal without instituting a new designation process. If said
commission fails to act within fifteen (15) days, the designation proposal
shall be forwarded to the City Commission for final action.
   F.   Upon receipt of the proposal by the City Commission, they may designate
the recommended area as a Historic District, historic structure or historic
landmark, or reject or modify the proposal.
   G.   Approval of the City Commission shall be manifested by approval of an
ordinance officially designating the site, landmark or district as historic; if
a district is to be designated, the ordinance shall be an amendment (Overlay
Zone) to the Zoning Ordinance, in accordance therewith. (2007 Code § 4-84)
10-5-5: CRITERIA FOR EVALUATION OF PROPOSED DESIGNATIONS:
The following criteria shall be used in the evaluation of proposed historic
landmarks, historic sites or Historic Districts:
   A.   Character, interest or value as a part of the development, heritage or
cultural characteristics of the community, State of Oklahoma, Nation or other
societies; or
   B.   Location of the site of a notable historical event; or
   C.   Identification with a person or persons who contributed notably to the
cultural development of the community, State, Nation or society; or
   D.   Relationship to properties which are significant and preserved, or
which are eligible for preservation; or
   E.   Embodiment of distinctive elements of architectural design, detail,
materials or craftsmanship related to a uniqueness to the area, or the related
distinctiveness of a craftsman, master builder or architect, or a style or
innovation; or
   F.   Archeological value, in the sense that the site has, has produced, or
can be expected to yield, based on physical evidence, information affecting
knowledge of history or prehistory; or
   G.   Value as an aspect of community sentiment or public pride; or
   H.   An established and familiar visual feature of a neighborhood, the
community or the skyline owing to its unique location or singular physical
characteristics. (2007 Code § 4-85)
10-5-6: VOLUNTARY RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS:
The owner of any historic landmark or historic site may, at any time following
such designation of this property, enter into a restrictive covenant on the
subject property after negotiation with the Preservation Commission. Said
commission may assist the owner in preparing such covenant in the interest of
preserving the historic landmark or historic site, and the owner shall record
such covenant in the Office of the County Clerk and shall notify the City Clerk
of such covenant and the conditions thereof. If the covenant involves any
assumption of responsibility by the City, the City Commission shall first
review and approve the document, indicating approval by the Mayor's signature
thereon. (2007 Code § 4-86)
10-5-7: GENERAL DESIGN REVIEW POLICIES:
   A.   The Preservation Commission shall be charged with the responsibility
for reviewing requests for building and demolition permits for designated
historic structures or within any area designated as a Historic District, and
issuing or denying Certificates of Appropriateness for applicable types of such
requests. It is the purpose of this section to specify for commission members
policies and criteria that they shall follow in reaching decisions on matters
relative to such changes.
   B.   Review criteria, procedural policies and consequences of decisions will
extend beyond the tenure of any Preservation Commission members. It is
essential that policies and practices be based on consistency and basic
preservation guidelines. Highest priority should go to the preservation and
restoration of significant structures (historically and architecturally) and
sites that express the unique characteristics of the particular periods in
which they were built.
   C.   The Preservation Commission shall utilize, in addition to those
criteria in section
10-5-8 of this chapter, the "Secretary of the Interior's Standards for
Rehabilitation". These standards are as follows:
Standard 1: Every reasonable effort shall be made to provide a compatible use
for a property which requires minimal alteration of the building, structure or
site and its environment, or to use a property for its originally intended
purpose.
Standard 2: The distinguishing original qualities or character of a building,
structure or site and its environment should not be destroyed. The removal or
alteration of any historic material or distinctive architectural features
should be avoided when possible.
Standard 3: All buildings, structures and sites shall be recognized as products
of their own time. Alterations that have no historical basis and which seek to
create an earlier appearance shall be discouraged.
Standard 4: Changes which may have taken place in the course of time are
evidence of the history and development of a building, structure or site and
its environment. These changes may have acquired significance in their own
right, and this significance shall be recognized and respected.
Standard 5: Distinctive stylistic features or examples of skilled craftsmanship
which characterize a building, structure or site shall be treated with
sensitivity.
Standard 6: Deteriorated architectural features shall be repaired rather than
replaced, wherever possible. In the event replacement is necessary, the new
material should match the material being replaced in composition, design,
color, texture and other visual qualities. Repair or replacement of missing
architectural features should be based on accurate duplications of features,
substantiated by historic, physical or pictorial evidence rather than on
conjectural designs or the availability of different architectural elements
from other buildings or structures.
Standard 7: The surface cleaning of structures shall be undertaken with the
gentlest means possible. Sandblasting and other cleaning methods that will
damage historic building materials shall not be undertaken.
Standard 8: Every reasonable effort shall be made to protect and preserve
archeological resources affected by, or adjacent to, any project.
Standard 9: Contemporary design for alterations and additions to existing
properties shall not be discouraged when such alterations and additions do not
destroy significant historical, architectural or cultural material, and such
design is compatible with the size, scale, color, material and character of the
property, neighborhood or environment.
Standard 10: Wherever possible, new additions or alterations to structures
shall be done in such a manner that if such additions or alterations were to be
removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the structure would
be unimpaired. (2007 Code § 4-87)
10-5-8: SPECIFIC DESIGN REVIEW CRITERIA:
   A.   The purpose of historic/architectural design review is to protect
property values and to promote the public welfare by promoting new construction
and rehabilitation or alteration of buildings, in the proper proportions, and
in general and reasonable harmony with the existing buildings in the
surrounding area; a supplemental purpose is to encourage design which is
compatible with the community's historic architecture.
   B.   In such instances where historic/architectural design review is
required, the procedure for such review will commence following application for
a building permit. Upon receipt of said application, under conditions as set
forth in this chapter or for a particular zoning district, the applicant will
submit to the Municipal building inspector plans indicating accurate elevation
drawings or photographs of each facade, and sufficient detailing to indicate
materials, colors, texture, light reflecting characteristics, and special
features intended for the building. This may be supplemented by sketches as
deemed necessary by the applicant to present the intended design. Submission of
actual samples of building materials is also encouraged.
   C.   The Preservation Commission shall utilize the following specific
criteria (in addition to the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for
Rehabilitation) in reaching decisions on proposals presented for review. These
criteria permit the use of modern fabrics, but do not encourage imitation or
fake facades; they encourage the designers of new buildings or alterations to
existing structures to consider the relationship of the proposal to that of the
total character of the streetscape or of any Historic District. If the proposal
involves an established Historic Zoning District, provisions and procedures of
the appropriate zoning district must also be met and followed.
      1.   Architectural Details: Architectural details must be considered with
respect to their relationships to the structure in question and those adjacent
(details may include, but are not limited to, cornices, lintels, arches,
quoins, balustrades and iron work, chimneys, etc.).
      2.   Color: The existence of a predominant color scheme, whether natural
or colored by time, must be considered in work on a new or restored structure
or area.
      3.   Directional Expression: Structural shape, openings or architectural
details that provide directional expression (i.e., a predominantly vertical,
horizontal or other directional character to the buildings' front facades) must
be considered.
      4.   Entrances And Porch Projections: Entrances, doors, porches and other
projections must relate to the sidewalk areas.
      5.   Front Facades: Building fronts must relate to each other, in both
width and height.
      6.   Height: As a general rule, new buildings or modifications to
existing ones should be the height of within ten percent (10%) of the average
height of existing adjacent buildings.
      7.   Ground Cover: If there exists a pattern or predominance in the area,
with respect to the use of brick pavers, cobblestones, granite blocks or other
materials, it must receive priority consideration for continuance.
      8.   Landscaping: A predominance of a specific quality and quantity of
landscaping must be considered, although emphasis shall be with the continuity
of such landscaping.
      9.   Materials: The predominant materials utilized, such as brick, stone,
stucco or wood siding on other adjacent or surrounding structures, should
relate to those used on the new or restored structure or area.
      10.   Openings: Windows and doors must relate to each other, in each
building and with other windows and doors in adjacent buildings.
      11.   Roof Shapes: Buildings must have compatible roof shapes.
      12.   Scale: The size of units of construction and architectural detail
must relate to the human scale. Consideration must also be given to relating
building mass to open space. The predominant element of scale may be brick or
stone units, window or door openings, porches or balconies, etc.
      13.   Spacing: Buildings and spaces must create a recurrent pattern that
is relatively ordered.
      14.   Textures: The area's predominant textures, whether they are smooth
(such as smooth stucco) or rough (such as brick with tooled joints, or
horizontal wood siding or other textures) must relate to those used on the new
or restored structure or area.
      15.   Walls Of Continuity: Physical ingredients, such as brick walls,
wrought iron fences, evergreen landscape masses, building facades, or
combinations of these, must be continued, to allow cohesive walls of enclosure
along the street. (2007 Code § 4-88)
10-5-9: DESIGN REVIEW PROCESS; CERTIFICATES AND CLEARANCES:
   A.   All requests for building permits for structures within a Historic
District and for those designated as historic landmarks or historic sites must
first receive a Certificate of Appropriateness and, therefore, shall be
referred to the Preservation Commission, which shall have a specified period of
time to review each request.
   B.   The Certificate of Appropriateness is required before a building permit
is issued for any work to occur in a Historic District or on a designated
historic landmark or historic site.
   C.   The commission may use such time to discuss the proposed changes with
the owner of the structure in question and may permit the Municipal building
inspector to issue the building permit before such period has expired;
following the review, the commission shall issue or deny issuance of, a
Certificate of Appropriateness for the reviewed work.
   D.   This shall not prohibit the granting of a building permit by the
Municipal building inspector after such period has expired, if the commission
has not made a decision on the proposal. (2007 Code § 4-89)
CHAPTER 6
WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS
SECTION:
10-6-1: Definitions
10-6-2: Building Permit Requirements
10-6-3: Insurance Required
10-6-4: Construction And Maintenance Requirements
10-6-5: System Nonoperational; Abandonment
10-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions, as are used in this chapter, shall have the meanings
shown below:
OVER SPEED CONTROL: A mechanism used to limit the speed of blade rotation below
the design limits of the Wind Energy Conversion System.
SITE: The plot of land where the Wind Energy Conversion System is to be placed.
The site could be publicly or privately owned (by an individual or a group of
individuals controlling single or adjacent properties).
SWEPT AREA: The largest area of the Wind Energy Conversion System which
extracts energy from the wind stream. In a conventional propeller type Wind
Energy Conversion System, there is a direct relationship between swept area and
the rotor diameter.
TOTAL HEIGHT: The height of the tower and the farthest vertical extension of
the Wind Energy Conversion System.
WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEM (WECS): A machine that converts the kinetic
energy in the wind into a usable form (commonly known as a wind turbine or
windmill). The Wind Energy Conversion System includes all parts of the system,
and shall be considered as a structure. (2007 Code § 4-108)
10-6-2: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Building permit applications 1  for a Wind Energy Conversion System
shall be accompanied by a site plan drawn in sufficient detail to clearly
describe the following:
      1.   Property lines and physical dimensions of the site;
      2.   Location, approximate dimensions and types of major existing
structures and uses on the site;
      3.   Location and elevation of the proposed Wind Energy Conversion
System;
      4.   Location of all aboveground utility lines on site or within a
distance radius equal to the total height of the Wind Energy Conversion System;
      5.   Location and size of structures and trees over thirty five feet
(35') in height, which are within a five hundred foot (500') radius of the
proposed Wind Energy Conversion System; for purposes of this requirement,
electrical transmission and distribution lines, antennas and slender or open
lattice towers are not considered structures; and
      6.   The zoning designation of immediate and adjacent sites.
   B.   Before a building permit may be issued, all requirements of this
chapter must be met. This chapter covers those Wind Energy Conversion Systems
whose swept area is one thousand (1,000) square feet or less; for conventional
propeller Wind Energy Conversion Systems, this would be approximately thirty
five feet (35') or less in diameter. (Nonelectrical windmills used for pumping
water may be exempted from the remaining provisions of this chapter.)
   C.   Building permit applications shall be accompanied by standard drawings
of the structural components of the Wind Energy Conversion System, including
support structure, tower, base and footings. Drawings and any necessary
calculations shall be certified in writing by a registered professional
engineer or manufacturer's representative, to show that the system complies
with the adopted Building Code. (This certification would normally be supplied
by the manufacturer.) Where the structural components or installation vary from
the standard design or specification, the proposed modifications shall be
certified by a registered professional engineer for compliance with the
structural design provisions of the adopted Building Code.
   D.   Building permit applications shall be accompanied by a line drawing
identifying the electrical components of the system to be installed, in
sufficient detail to allow for a determination that the manner of installation
conforms to the adopted Electrical Code. The application shall include a
statement from a registered professional engineer indicating that the
electrical system conforms with good engineering practices and complies with
said Electrical Code. (This certification would normally be supplied by the
manufacturer.) All equipment and materials shall be used or installed in
accordance with such drawings and diagrams. Where the electrical components of
an installation vary from the standard design or specifications, the proposed
modifications shall be reviewed and certified by a registered professional
engineer for compliance with the requirements of said Electrical Code and good
engineering practices. (2007 Code § 4-108)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  10-4-1 of this title.
10-6-3: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
The applicant, owner, lessee or assignee shall maintain a current insurance
policy which will cover installation and operation of the Wind Energy
Conversion System at all times. Said policy shall provide a minimum of one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property and personal liability
coverage. (2007 Code § 4-108; amd. 2019 Code)
10-6-4: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Each Wind Energy Conversion System must be equipped with both manual
and automatic controls to limit the rotational speed of the blade below the
design limits of the rotor. The application must include a statement by a
registered professional engineer certifying that the rotor and over speed
controls have been designed and fabricated for the proposed use in accordance
with good engineering practices. The engineer should also certify the
structural compatibility of possible towers with available rotors. (This
certification would normally be supplied by the manufacturer.)
   B.   Anchor points for guy wires for the Wind Energy Conversion System tower
shall be located within property lines and not on or across any aboveground
electric transmission or distribution lines. The point of ground attachment for
the guy wires shall be enclosed by a fence six feet (6') high, or the Wind
Energy Conversion System shall be set back from the property line or site
parameters the total height of the Wind Energy Conversion System.
   C.   Towers should have either a tower climbing apparatus located no closer
than twelve feet (12') from the ground, a locked anticlimb device installed on
the tower, or the tower shall be completely enclosed by a locked, protective
fence at least six feet (6') high.
   D.   The Wind Energy Conversion System shall meet the requirements of any
existing Municipal noise regulations.
   E.   The Wind Energy Conversion System shall be operated such that no
disruptive electromagnetic interference is caused. If it has been demonstrated
to the Municipal building inspector that a Wind Energy Conversion System is
causing harmful interference, the operator shall be required to promptly
mitigate the harmful interference.
   F.   At least one sign shall be posted at the base of the tower warning of
electrical shock or high voltage.
   G.   The minimum height of the lowest part of the Wind Energy Conversion
System shall be thirty feet (30') above the highest existing major structure or
any tree within a two hundred fifty foot (250') radius. For purposes of this
requirement, electrical transmission and distribution lines, antennas and
slender or open lattice towers are not considered structures.
   H.   The Wind Energy Conversion System shall be located such that the
farthest extension of the apparatus does not cross any site lines.
   I.   For Wind Energy Conversion Systems which will be interconnected to a
utility grid, no wind turbine shall be installed until evidence has been given
that the utility company has been notified in writing. (2007 Code § 4-108)
10-6-5: SYSTEM NONOPERATIONAL; ABANDONMENT:
If a Wind Energy Conversion System is not maintained in operational condition
for a period of one year and poses a potential safety hazard, the owner or
operator shall take expeditious action to remedy the situation. If the City
determines that the Wind Energy Conversion System has been abandoned and poses
a safety hazard, the system shall be removed within forty five (45) days of
written notice to the owner or operator of the system. (2007 Code § 4-108)
CHAPTER 7
MANUFACTURED, MOBILE AND MODULAR HOUSING
SECTION:
10-7-1: Purpose
10-7-2: Definitions
10-7-3: Freestanding Mobile Homes
10-7-4: Nonresidential Mobile Homes Or Trailers
10-7-5: Minimum Housing Regulations For Mobile And Manufactured Homes
10-7-6: Subdivisions
10-7-7: Treatment Of Modular Housing
10-7-8: Penalty
10-7-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   The purpose of this chapter is to provide regulations for areas within
the corporate boundaries of the City wherein the location and development of
manufactured housing, mobile homes, mobile home parks, trailer parks,
manufactured and mobile home subdivisions and modular housing units or
additions may be safely continued and encouraged.
   B.   The regulations set forth in this chapter are designed to promote
stable neighborhoods, prevent health and safety hazards and encourage the
economical and orderly development and operation of manufactured housing and
mobile home parks and subdivisions, trailer parks and modular housing units and
additions. (2007 Code § 10-1)
10-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, words and phrases shall
have the meanings indicated hereinbelow:
BUFFER PLANTING STRIP: A visual screening facility, consisting of not less than
one row of shrubbery spaced not more than eight feet (8') apart, which will
grow to a height of not less than twelve feet (12') in less than five (5)
years, under normal circumstances; such a strip may, as an alternative, consist
of an earthen berm or solid fencing, or any combination of earthen berm,
fencing and/or landscaping, all of which shall total at least eight feet (8')
in height.
CITY BUILDING INSPECTOR: The City building inspector of the City of Waurika,
Oklahoma, or an authorized agent.
GREENBELT PLANTING STRIP: A landscaped area, not less than twenty feet (20') in
width, used along all subdivision boundaries; such greenbelt planting strip
shall be composed of: a) one row of deciduous and/or evergreen trees, spaced
not more than forty feet (40') apart, b) not less than three (3) rows of
shrubs, spaced not more than thirty feet (30') apart, and c) not less than
three (3) rows of shrubs, spaced not more than eight feet (8') apart, all of
which shrubs must eventually be capable of growing to at least four feet (4')
